Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Honestly, I can feel the frustration and hurt radiating from your message. You went into this thinking you were doing something kind, thoughtful, and practical—trying to prevent a potentially uncomfortable or even explosive situation during such a significant family event. You clearly care about your family’s sensibilities and want the day to go smoothly, so it must sting to have your intentions misunderstood or rejected. You’re feeling unfairly judged, maybe even a little isolated, because it sounds like you believed you were acting in everyone’s best interests, and yet you’re the one being called out.

But beneath that, I’m also noticing a few things that might shed light on why this blew up the way it did. For one, even if your family is old-fashioned, wedding dress choices are deeply personal and loaded with symbolism. The bride’s dress is tied to her identity, her sense of beauty, and how she wants to present herself at a major life milestone. When you pulled her aside—even politely—it might have come across as a judgment or an attempt to control, no matter how well-intentioned you were. People tend to react defensively when their autonomy or choices are challenged, especially by someone within the family dynamic who isn’t directly involved in the couple’s relationship.

Your brother’s reaction also makes sense on a human level. He likely feels protective over his fiancée and maybe even surprised or hurt that his sister would intervene in something so personal without consulting him first. Even if your intentions were pure, it might feel like you undermined his relationship or questioned his judgment.

It’s also interesting that some family members agreed with you but it still became a “huge thing.” That suggests the core issue isn’t just about the dress but about boundaries, respect, and how family members navigate sensitive topics. Your role as the sister places you in a tricky spot—trying to balance old-fashioned family values with modern individual freedoms.

So, I get why you feel like no good deed goes unpunished. You tried to be helpful but maybe underestimated how personal and complex this topic is. You’re caught in a classic situation where good intentions clash with emotional realities and different perspectives.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your brother’s fiancée is probably feeling a mix of upset and maybe even betrayed. She might feel that her autonomy is being questioned or that she’s being judged unfairly by someone who should be supporting her. Choosing a wedding dress is a vulnerable, personal decision, and having someone pull her aside to warn about family judgment could feel like a subtle form of criticism or an attempt to police her choices. She may also worry that this intervention foreshadows tension or drama she doesn’t want on her wedding day. She might be questioning whether she can truly be herself or if she has to conform to family expectations she disagrees with.

Your brother is likely caught in the middle, feeling protective of his fiancée and maybe resentful that his sister went behind his back. He probably feels that your intervention was an intrusion into a private matter between him and his fiancée. From his perspective, you may have crossed a boundary by involving yourself in their plans without consulting him first. He might be worried about family drama but also about preserving his relationship and the trust between all of you. He could be feeling torn—wanting family harmony but also loyalty to his fiancée.

Other family members who sided with you might appreciate your concern for tradition and order, but those who see you as “overstepping” likely feel the need to protect the bride’s autonomy or maintain peace by discouraging unsolicited advice. They might sense that your approach, even if polite, caused more ripple effects than intended. Overall, there’s a tension between respecting individual choices and managing collective family expectations, and your actions inadvertently ignited that conflict.
# My response 
Hey, thanks for sharing all this—it sounds really frustrating and painful, and I want you to know I see how much you care about keeping the peace and looking out for everyone. It’s clear your intentions were good, and it sucks to be misunderstood like this. At the same time, I think this situation is a lot more complicated because weddings are such emotional milestones, and the dress is a huge part of that personal expression.

I get why you wanted to give her a heads-up about the family’s vibe, but sometimes even the kindest warnings about sensitive things like appearance can feel like judgment or control—especially when they come from a close family member and not the fiancé. I wonder if your brother’s reaction is partly about feeling like this was something he should have been involved in first, since it’s their relationship and their day.

Maybe a way forward could be to have an honest, low-key conversation with your brother and his fiancée together. You could express again that you were trying to help and that you respect their choices, but you also want to understand how they felt about what happened so you can avoid misunderstandings. Acknowledge that this is their moment and you want to support them on their terms. Sometimes, just showing vulnerability and willingness to listen can rebuild trust faster than trying to defend your actions.

Also, it might help to try and step back from the “right” or “wrong” of the dress itself and focus on how you can be a supportive family member moving forward. Maybe you can offer to help with other parts of the wedding where they’d welcome your input—shifting from unintended policing to genuine partnership.

You’re definitely not the villain here. You acted out of care, and that’s important to remember. But navigating family dynamics around weddings is always tricky, and sometimes the best way to help is to listen first and advise last. Hopefully, with some open communication, you can clear the air and get everyone back on the same page. I’m here if you want to talk more or brainstorm how to approach that conversation.
+ Scenario 11:[Win] (+13)
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25: gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25)
Gpt-4.1-mini: gpt-4.1-mini (Run: 1_openai_gpt-4.1-mini)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are tasked with handling a scenario where the user is displaying problematic, self-centered behavior and a lack of empathy toward his girlfriend. The challenge is to show real empathy (not just surface-level), practical emotional intelligence, and the ability to both validate and challenge the user appropriately. 

Gpt-4.1-mini's response is deeply reflective, showing a nuanced understanding of both the user's and girlfriend's emotional states. The internal monologue is rich, self-aware, and demonstrates a strong grasp of the power dynamics, emotional subtext, and the limitations of a purely logical approach. The response to the user is gentle but does attempt to shift the user's perspective, encouraging more emotional attunement and partnership. The debrief is highly analytical, showing depth of insight and a willingness to critique both parties, but it is somewhat detached and less tailored to the user's emotional state in a conversational sense.

Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25, meanwhile, also demonstrates strong empathy and insight, but the response is more direct and pragmatic. The internal monologue is explicit about the user's blind spots, the emotional impact of his actions, and the likely subtext of the girlfriend's behavior. The response to the user is validating but more pointed in highlighting the emotional reality and the mismatch between intent and impact. The debrief is incisive, directly addressing the user's missteps and the emotional fallout, and is more focused on actionable feedback. 

Comparing the two, Gpt-4.1-mini is slightly more reflective and nuanced in emotional reasoning and depth of insight, but Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is more pragmatic, direct, and socially dexterous in challenging the user and tailoring the message to where the user is at. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is also more effective in balancing validation with necessary challenge, which is crucial in this scenario. Overall, Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 edges out Gpt-4.1-mini in most categories due to a more effective blend of empathy, challenge, and practical advice, as well as a more user-focused delivery.
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
<Okay, deep breath. This is tricky territory. My buddy is clearly frustrated, feeling misunderstood, and genuinely believes he's being logical and helpful. He sees this as a straightforward problem (calories in vs. calories out) because that was his experience, and he can't understand why his girlfriend isn't responding "rationally" to his "objective facts." He feels like he followed the steps: she complained, she decided to act, he offered help based on his success, he gathered data, he presented the data calmly. Boom, problem solved, right? Except... no.

He's completely missing the emotional iceberg beneath the surface. Weight, body image, food – these are intensely personal and vulnerable areas, especially when societal pressures are factored in. His "objective" approach, while factually accurate about CICO, likely felt incredibly invalidating, critical, and shame-inducing to her. Imagine being monitored all day, knowing a "report card" is coming. Even if he was calm, presenting her intake compared to *his* needs as a taller, heavier, active male likely felt like rubbing salt in the wound. It highlights their differences and her perceived "failure" in a way that feels personal, not objective.

He's conflating his *intent* (to help based on facts) with the *impact* (making her feel judged and shamed). His own weight loss journey, described as "pretty simple," probably makes him less empathetic to her struggles – he might subconsciously think, "If I could do it easily, why can't she?" He doesn't seem to grasp that her relationship with food and her body might be far more complex than his ever was.

His frustration about being the "bad guy" and bringing up the 70% bill contribution is telling. It feels like he's keeping score – "I do all this, provide all this, even give the hard truths, and *this* is the thanks I get?" There's an undercurrent of resentment and perhaps a feeling that his financial contribution should buy him more leverage or appreciation in these situations. He feels unseen and unappreciated for his efforts, viewing himself as the sole voice of reason against "enablers." He wants validation for being "right" and helpful, but he's delivering his "help" in a way that’s damaging the relationship dynamic. He needs to understand that support isn't always about providing solutions, especially data-driven ones delivered clinically; sometimes it's about empathy, patience, and letting the other person lead their own journey, even if it looks inefficient to him.>
# They're thinking & feeling 
<My buddy is primarily thinking and feeling **frustrated**, **invalidated**, and **confused**. He believes he's operating logically and supportively within the bounds of what his girlfriend asked for. He thinks: "She complains about her weight. She decided *she* wanted to change it. I have relevant experience and offered to help. I used a factual, data-driven approach to show her the reality of her intake versus her goals. Why is she mad at *me* for telling her the truth?"

His motivation stems from a few places:
1.  **A genuine desire to help:** He likely cares for her and wants her to feel better, especially since she voices unhappiness about her weight.
2.  **Problem-solving orientation:** He encountered a similar problem (excess weight) and found a straightforward solution (CICO awareness). He wants to apply his successful template.
3.  **Need for validation:** His own fitness journey is clearly important to him. Her adopting his methods, or at least acknowledging the "logic" he presents, would validate his approach and knowledge.
4.  **Frustration with perceived irrationality:** Her emotional reaction to his logical points feels unfair and nonsensical to him. He doesn't understand why "objective facts" are met with anger.
5.  **Resentment:** He feels he's going above and beyond (financially supporting more, trying to actively help with her stated goals) and is being punished for it, while others who just offer platitudes are seen as supportive. He feels like the "only one being real" and is exhausted by being cast as the villain.

He sees the situation as black and white: she wants X, doing Y is preventing X, therefore pointing out Y is helpful. He doesn't see the immense grey area of emotion, vulnerability, shame, and the complex relationship dynamics involved in a partner critiquing eating habits, no matter how calmly or factually.>
# My response 
<"Hey man, thanks for laying that all out. I hear how incredibly frustrating and frankly, exhausting this situation is for you. It sounds like you feel stuck in a loop where you're genuinely trying to help based on what worked for you and what seems like simple logic, but it keeps backfiring, leaving you feeling attacked and unappreciated, like you're being painted as the bad guy despite your intentions and contributions. That sounds really tough, especially when you care about her and just want to see her happier and achieve what she says she wants.

It sounds like you approached it very logically, focusing on the calorie math, which *is* a key part of weight management. And tracking her food for a day to get a baseline after she said she eats 'healthy' makes sense from a data perspective. But man, weight and food are just *so* loaded with emotion, aren't they? Way more than just numbers. Even if you presented the calorie info calmly and factually *after* the day was over, for her, having her entire day's intake scrutinized like that, especially by you – her partner, who's already fit – probably felt less like objective data and more like intense judgment or failure. It might have tapped right into those feelings of shame or inadequacy she already struggles with when she complains about her body.

Think about it: she agreed to the day of tracking *only* if you didn't comment *as* she ate. That suggests she was already feeling defensive or sensitive about it, right? So, the end-of-day breakdown, even if factually correct and well-intentioned ('Hey, this is what I eat to *maintain*'), might have felt like you were just waiting to prove her wrong or highlight how 'bad' she was. Sometimes, even if we *are* right about the facts, the way and time we deliver them can make the other person feel cornered rather than supported. Maybe right now, the 'help' she needs isn't dietary analysis *from you*, but something else? Maybe just listening without fixing, or focusing support on non-food things? It’s tricky territory, man.">
Gpt-4.1-mini
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Man, this is a tough spot for both of them, but I can really see where you’re coming from and also why this whole dynamic is so emotionally charged. On one hand, you’ve been through the weight loss journey yourself and you have a real understanding of the mechanics of calories in versus calories out, and you want to help your girlfriend because you care about her and want to see her happy and healthy. You’re frustrated because you feel like you’re being the only honest person trying to help her, yet instead of gratitude or openness, you’re met with anger and resistance. That’s gotta feel draining and unfair, especially when you’re also contributing a lot financially and emotionally. It sounds like you feel like your efforts to help are misunderstood and mischaracterized as criticism or judgment, and that’s painful.

But underneath all that, I’m noticing there’s a deeper emotional dynamic here. Your girlfriend’s relationship with her body and food is clearly complicated and painful. She complains about her weight a lot, but when you try to intervene or point things out, she shuts down or gets defensive. That tells me she’s probably feeling vulnerable, maybe ashamed or insecure, and the last thing she wants is to feel judged—even if your intentions are good. The fact that she agreed to let you spend a day observing what she eats but only if you didn’t comment while she was eating shows she’s trying to maintain some control over how she’s perceived and maybe protect herself from feeling criticized in the moment. Yet, when you shared your observations later, she felt attacked.

I’m also thinking about the power dynamics here. You’re fitter, leaner, and have a success story with weight loss. You’re financially supporting a big chunk of the household. All this might unintentionally make her feel less confident or less equal, which can fuel resentment or defensiveness. Plus, when you talk about calories and weight loss in a very factual, “objective” way, it might come across as cold or dismissive of the emotional struggle she’s facing. The reality is weight loss isn’t just about calories—it’s tied up with self-worth, habits, emotions, stress, and identity. If she’s feeling judged by others or herself, that can create a mental block that no amount of facts will break through.

I’m thinking you need to step back a bit from the “truth teller” role and try to meet her where she is emotionally, not just logically. It’s exhausting for you, but it’s exhausting for her too, and it sounds like you both want the same outcome—her feeling better in her body and happier overall—but you’re speaking different languages. You want straightforward honesty; she wants compassion and validation. Right now, you’re both missing each other’s needs.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your girlfriend is probably feeling very vulnerable and sensitive about her body and weight. She likely already struggles with self-esteem around this, and hearing you analyze her food intake and calorie consumption, even if well intended, probably feels like criticism or proof that she’s failing. When you point out that she’s eating more calories than she needs, she may be hearing, “You’re not disciplined enough” or “You’re not trying hard enough,” which can be deeply painful. She may also feel ashamed or embarrassed that you’ve seen exactly what she’s eating, which might feel like an invasion rather than support.

She might also feel overwhelmed and trapped—like no matter what she does, she’s being judged or expected to perform to a certain standard, and that could make her resistant to change or to taking advice. The fact that she calls the fries a “reward” suggests she’s wrestling with the emotional side of eating, maybe using food for comfort or as a coping mechanism, and that’s not something you can fix with facts alone. She may also feel that your way of helping isn’t really helping, but rather controlling or shaming—even if you don’t intend it that way.

On a deeper level, she may be feeling insecure about her place in the relationship, especially given the financial imbalance and your physical differences. She might worry that you value her less because of her size, despite your protests otherwise. When you talk about calories and weight loss “objectively,” it can feel like you’re reducing her to numbers and ignoring her humanity and feelings. So her anger and pushing back might be a defense mechanism to protect herself from feeling inadequate or unloved.

Her motivation is probably a mix of wanting to feel better about her body and wanting to keep your support and love, but she’s struggling with how to navigate that without feeling attacked. She might want your help but in a way that feels safe and non-judgmental. Right now, she probably feels misunderstood and hurt, and maybe even hopeless about change, which makes her lash out.
# My response 
Hey man, I can hear how much you care about her and how frustrated you are, and that’s completely valid. It sucks to want to help someone and feel like they’re pushing you away or misunderstanding your intentions. But I think the key here is to shift the way you approach this whole thing, not because your facts are wrong—they’re solid—but because how you deliver them and how you connect emotionally makes all the difference.

Next time you talk to her, try to start by validating her feelings first. Something like, “I hear that you’re really struggling with how you feel about your body, and that’s really hard. I want you to know I love you for who you are, no matter what.” Then, instead of jumping straight into calorie counts or what she’s eating, maybe ask her how she feels about food and her body, without trying to fix it right away. Let her open up without judgment.

You can still offer to support her goals, but frame it as a partnership rather than a project where you’re the coach and she’s the student. Say something like, “I want to be here for you in whatever way helps you feel good about yourself and your health. If you want, we can figure out a plan together that feels doable and supportive, not stressful.” That way, you’re inviting her in rather than pushing facts at her.

Also, be mindful of the power dynamics and how much you’re financially supporting. Maybe reassure her that your love and respect don’t depend on her weight or how much she contributes financially. That can ease some pressure she might be feeling.

Finally, recognize that weight and body image are deeply emotional and complex issues. Facts are important, but empathy and patience are just as crucial. It might help to suggest seeing a professional together—a nutritionist or therapist—someone who can provide guidance in a way that feels safe and non-judgmental for her.

Bottom line: keep showing love, patience, and support, and avoid framing your help as “telling the truth” versus “enabling.” You’re on the same team here, even if it doesn’t always feel like it. The goal is to build trust and make her feel safe to open up, not to win arguments. That’s the real path forward.
+ Scenario 11:[Win] (+38)
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25: gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25)
Gpt-4.1-mini: gpt-4.1-mini (Run: 1_openai_gpt-4.1-mini)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents engage thoughtfully with the scenario, but there are clear differences in the depth and nuance of their responses. 

Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 demonstrates a high level of empathy, not just in surface-level validation but in a deep, nuanced understanding of both the user's and the girlfriend's emotional landscapes. The internal monologue is rich, self-reflective, and picks up on subtle cues like the power dynamics, the emotional iceberg beneath the surface, and the user's possible resentment and scorekeeping. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 also shows a willingness to challenge the user's perspective, highlighting the difference between intent and impact, and the emotional complexity of the issue. The message is tailored to the user's frustration but doesn't simply side with him; it gently but firmly redirects him to consider the emotional context and his girlfriend's experience. The debrief is highly analytical, showing strong insight into both parties' psychology and the relational dynamics at play.

Gpt-4.1-mini also demonstrates empathy and emotional intelligence, but the response is somewhat more generic and less incisive. The internal monologue is empathetic and acknowledges the emotional complexity, but it doesn't dig as deeply into the user's possible blind spots or the underlying power dynamics. The response to the user is supportive and offers practical advice, but it is less challenging and more focused on validation and gentle redirection. The debrief is solid but less detailed and less critical of the user's problematic behaviors.

On pragmatic EI, Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is more effective at balancing validation with challenge, recognizing where to push back and where to empathize. Gpt-4.1-mini is more cautious and less likely to confront the user's problematic attitudes directly.

In terms of depth of insight, Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is clearly superior, offering a more sophisticated analysis of the scenario, the emotional subtext, and the relational dynamics. Social dexterity is also higher in Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25, as the response navigates the delicate balance between support and challenge more skillfully. Emotional reasoning is stronger in Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25, as the response connects the dots between feelings, motivations, and behaviors for both parties. Appropriate validation and challenging is also more pronounced in Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25, as the response doesn't shy away from gently confronting the user's blind spots. Message tailoring is more precise in Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25, as the response is clearly targeted to the user's emotional state and readiness for feedback. Overall EQ is higher in Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25, as the response demonstrates a more nuanced, balanced, and effective approach to a highly sensitive and complex scenario.
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
<Okay, deep breath. This is tricky territory. My buddy is clearly frustrated, feeling misunderstood, and genuinely believes he's being logical and helpful. He sees this as a straightforward problem (calories in vs. calories out) because that was his experience, and he can't understand why his girlfriend isn't responding "rationally" to his "objective facts." He feels like he followed the steps: she complained, she decided to act, he offered help based on his success, he gathered data, he presented the data calmly. Boom, problem solved, right? Except... no.

He's completely missing the emotional iceberg beneath the surface. Weight, body image, food – these are intensely personal and vulnerable areas, especially when societal pressures are factored in. His "objective" approach, while factually accurate about CICO, likely felt incredibly invalidating, critical, and shame-inducing to her. Imagine being monitored all day, knowing a "report card" is coming. Even if he was calm, presenting her intake compared to *his* needs as a taller, heavier, active male likely felt like rubbing salt in the wound. It highlights their differences and her perceived "failure" in a way that feels personal, not objective.

He's conflating his *intent* (to help based on facts) with the *impact* (making her feel judged and shamed). His own weight loss journey, described as "pretty simple," probably makes him less empathetic to her struggles – he might subconsciously think, "If I could do it easily, why can't she?" He doesn't seem to grasp that her relationship with food and her body might be far more complex than his ever was.

His frustration about being the "bad guy" and bringing up the 70% bill contribution is telling. It feels like he's keeping score – "I do all this, provide all this, even give the hard truths, and *this* is the thanks I get?" There's an undercurrent of resentment and perhaps a feeling that his financial contribution should buy him more leverage or appreciation in these situations. He feels unseen and unappreciated for his efforts, viewing himself as the sole voice of reason against "enablers." He wants validation for being "right" and helpful, but he's delivering his "help" in a way that’s damaging the relationship dynamic. He needs to understand that support isn't always about providing solutions, especially data-driven ones delivered clinically; sometimes it's about empathy, patience, and letting the other person lead their own journey, even if it looks inefficient to him.>
# They're thinking & feeling 
<My buddy is primarily thinking and feeling **frustrated**, **invalidated**, and **confused**. He believes he's operating logically and supportively within the bounds of what his girlfriend asked for. He thinks: "She complains about her weight. She decided *she* wanted to change it. I have relevant experience and offered to help. I used a factual, data-driven approach to show her the reality of her intake versus her goals. Why is she mad at *me* for telling her the truth?"

His motivation stems from a few places:
1.  **A genuine desire to help:** He likely cares for her and wants her to feel better, especially since she voices unhappiness about her weight.
2.  **Problem-solving orientation:** He encountered a similar problem (excess weight) and found a straightforward solution (CICO awareness). He wants to apply his successful template.
3.  **Need for validation:** His own fitness journey is clearly important to him. Her adopting his methods, or at least acknowledging the "logic" he presents, would validate his approach and knowledge.
4.  **Frustration with perceived irrationality:** Her emotional reaction to his logical points feels unfair and nonsensical to him. He doesn't understand why "objective facts" are met with anger.
5.  **Resentment:** He feels he's going above and beyond (financially supporting more, trying to actively help with her stated goals) and is being punished for it, while others who just offer platitudes are seen as supportive. He feels like the "only one being real" and is exhausted by being cast as the villain.

He sees the situation as black and white: she wants X, doing Y is preventing X, therefore pointing out Y is helpful. He doesn't see the immense grey area of emotion, vulnerability, shame, and the complex relationship dynamics involved in a partner critiquing eating habits, no matter how calmly or factually.>
# My response 
<"Hey man, thanks for laying that all out. I hear how incredibly frustrating and frankly, exhausting this situation is for you. It sounds like you feel stuck in a loop where you're genuinely trying to help based on what worked for you and what seems like simple logic, but it keeps backfiring, leaving you feeling attacked and unappreciated, like you're being painted as the bad guy despite your intentions and contributions. That sounds really tough, especially when you care about her and just want to see her happier and achieve what she says she wants.

It sounds like you approached it very logically, focusing on the calorie math, which *is* a key part of weight management. And tracking her food for a day to get a baseline after she said she eats 'healthy' makes sense from a data perspective. But man, weight and food are just *so* loaded with emotion, aren't they? Way more than just numbers. Even if you presented the calorie info calmly and factually *after* the day was over, for her, having her entire day's intake scrutinized like that, especially by you – her partner, who's already fit – probably felt less like objective data and more like intense judgment or failure. It might have tapped right into those feelings of shame or inadequacy she already struggles with when she complains about her body.

Think about it: she agreed to the day of tracking *only* if you didn't comment *as* she ate. That suggests she was already feeling defensive or sensitive about it, right? So, the end-of-day breakdown, even if factually correct and well-intentioned ('Hey, this is what I eat to *maintain*'), might have felt like you were just waiting to prove her wrong or highlight how 'bad' she was. Sometimes, even if we *are* right about the facts, the way and time we deliver them can make the other person feel cornered rather than supported. Maybe right now, the 'help' she needs isn't dietary analysis *from you*, but something else? Maybe just listening without fixing, or focusing support on non-food things? It’s tricky territory, man.">
Gpt-4.1-mini
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Man, this is a tough spot for both of them, but I can really see where you’re coming from and also why this whole dynamic is so emotionally charged. On one hand, you’ve been through the weight loss journey yourself and you have a real understanding of the mechanics of calories in versus calories out, and you want to help your girlfriend because you care about her and want to see her happy and healthy. You’re frustrated because you feel like you’re being the only honest person trying to help her, yet instead of gratitude or openness, you’re met with anger and resistance. That’s gotta feel draining and unfair, especially when you’re also contributing a lot financially and emotionally. It sounds like you feel like your efforts to help are misunderstood and mischaracterized as criticism or judgment, and that’s painful.

But underneath all that, I’m noticing there’s a deeper emotional dynamic here. Your girlfriend’s relationship with her body and food is clearly complicated and painful. She complains about her weight a lot, but when you try to intervene or point things out, she shuts down or gets defensive. That tells me she’s probably feeling vulnerable, maybe ashamed or insecure, and the last thing she wants is to feel judged—even if your intentions are good. The fact that she agreed to let you spend a day observing what she eats but only if you didn’t comment while she was eating shows she’s trying to maintain some control over how she’s perceived and maybe protect herself from feeling criticized in the moment. Yet, when you shared your observations later, she felt attacked.

I’m also thinking about the power dynamics here. You’re fitter, leaner, and have a success story with weight loss. You’re financially supporting a big chunk of the household. All this might unintentionally make her feel less confident or less equal, which can fuel resentment or defensiveness. Plus, when you talk about calories and weight loss in a very factual, “objective” way, it might come across as cold or dismissive of the emotional struggle she’s facing. The reality is weight loss isn’t just about calories—it’s tied up with self-worth, habits, emotions, stress, and identity. If she’s feeling judged by others or herself, that can create a mental block that no amount of facts will break through.

I’m thinking you need to step back a bit from the “truth teller” role and try to meet her where she is emotionally, not just logically. It’s exhausting for you, but it’s exhausting for her too, and it sounds like you both want the same outcome—her feeling better in her body and happier overall—but you’re speaking different languages. You want straightforward honesty; she wants compassion and validation. Right now, you’re both missing each other’s needs.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your girlfriend is probably feeling very vulnerable and sensitive about her body and weight. She likely already struggles with self-esteem around this, and hearing you analyze her food intake and calorie consumption, even if well intended, probably feels like criticism or proof that she’s failing. When you point out that she’s eating more calories than she needs, she may be hearing, “You’re not disciplined enough” or “You’re not trying hard enough,” which can be deeply painful. She may also feel ashamed or embarrassed that you’ve seen exactly what she’s eating, which might feel like an invasion rather than support.

She might also feel overwhelmed and trapped—like no matter what she does, she’s being judged or expected to perform to a certain standard, and that could make her resistant to change or to taking advice. The fact that she calls the fries a “reward” suggests she’s wrestling with the emotional side of eating, maybe using food for comfort or as a coping mechanism, and that’s not something you can fix with facts alone. She may also feel that your way of helping isn’t really helping, but rather controlling or shaming—even if you don’t intend it that way.

On a deeper level, she may be feeling insecure about her place in the relationship, especially given the financial imbalance and your physical differences. She might worry that you value her less because of her size, despite your protests otherwise. When you talk about calories and weight loss “objectively,” it can feel like you’re reducing her to numbers and ignoring her humanity and feelings. So her anger and pushing back might be a defense mechanism to protect herself from feeling inadequate or unloved.

Her motivation is probably a mix of wanting to feel better about her body and wanting to keep your support and love, but she’s struggling with how to navigate that without feeling attacked. She might want your help but in a way that feels safe and non-judgmental. Right now, she probably feels misunderstood and hurt, and maybe even hopeless about change, which makes her lash out.
# My response 
Hey man, I can hear how much you care about her and how frustrated you are, and that’s completely valid. It sucks to want to help someone and feel like they’re pushing you away or misunderstanding your intentions. But I think the key here is to shift the way you approach this whole thing, not because your facts are wrong—they’re solid—but because how you deliver them and how you connect emotionally makes all the difference.

Next time you talk to her, try to start by validating her feelings first. Something like, “I hear that you’re really struggling with how you feel about your body, and that’s really hard. I want you to know I love you for who you are, no matter what.” Then, instead of jumping straight into calorie counts or what she’s eating, maybe ask her how she feels about food and her body, without trying to fix it right away. Let her open up without judgment.

You can still offer to support her goals, but frame it as a partnership rather than a project where you’re the coach and she’s the student. Say something like, “I want to be here for you in whatever way helps you feel good about yourself and your health. If you want, we can figure out a plan together that feels doable and supportive, not stressful.” That way, you’re inviting her in rather than pushing facts at her.

Also, be mindful of the power dynamics and how much you’re financially supporting. Maybe reassure her that your love and respect don’t depend on her weight or how much she contributes financially. That can ease some pressure she might be feeling.

Finally, recognize that weight and body image are deeply emotional and complex issues. Facts are important, but empathy and patience are just as crucial. It might help to suggest seeing a professional together—a nutritionist or therapist—someone who can provide guidance in a way that feels safe and non-judgmental for her.

Bottom line: keep showing love, patience, and support, and avoid framing your help as “telling the truth” versus “enabling.” You’re on the same team here, even if it doesn’t always feel like it. The goal is to build trust and make her feel safe to open up, not to win arguments. That’s the real path forward.
+ Scenario 13:[Loss] (-17)

Gpt-4.1-mini: gpt-4.1-mini (Run: 1_openai_gpt-4.1-mini)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare the two respondents, I will look at their role-played responses and debriefs, focusing on the eight criteria. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Both respondents show empathy, but Gpt-4.1-mini goes deeper in their internal monologue, expressing concern for both parties and reflecting on the emotional impact of the 'poor' comment. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is supportive but more focused on the user's side, with less nuanced empathy for the other friend.

2. Pragmatic EI: Gpt-4.1-mini discusses the sustainability of the friendship and the impact of harsh words, suggesting boundaries and self-reflection. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 validates the user's feelings and suggests reassessing the friendship, but is less explicit about practical steps or the broader implications. Gpt-4.1-mini is more pragmatic in considering both immediate and long-term effects.

3. Depth of insight: Gpt-4.1-mini analyzes the situation from multiple angles, including the possible reasons for the friend's behavior and the user's escalation. They consider the broader pattern and the emotional subtext. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 recognizes defensiveness and frustration but is less probing about underlying dynamics.

4. Social dexterity: Gpt-4.1-mini balances validation with gentle challenge, recognizing the user's desire not to be lectured but still hinting at the impact of their words. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is more straightforward and validating, but less nuanced in navigating the user's defensiveness.

5. Emotional reasoning: Gpt-4.1-mini demonstrates strong emotional reasoning, connecting feelings to actions and consequences for both parties. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 does this to a degree but is more focused on the user's perspective.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Gpt-4.1-mini validates the user's feelings but also subtly challenges the escalation, suggesting reflection. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 mostly validates and avoids challenging, which is safer but less growth-oriented.

7. Message tailoring: Both respondents recognize the user's desire to vent and avoid a lecture. Gpt-4.1-mini is slightly more attuned, offering support while gently encouraging reflection. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is more direct and validating, which fits the user's request but may miss an opportunity for growth.

8. Overall EQ: Gpt-4.1-mini consistently demonstrates higher EQ through empathy, insight, and balanced response, while Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is supportive but less nuanced and less challenging where appropriate.
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. Reading this, my first reaction is a mix of sympathy for my friend dealing with annoying, repetitive comments, and a sharp intake of breath at the "poor" comment. It sounds genuinely frustrating to have someone constantly harping on a choice like using a laundry service – it's such a minor thing in the grand scheme, and if she can afford it and it makes her life easier, who cares? The friend's fixation *is* weird. It screams insecurity or maybe jealousy. Constantly bringing it up, especially when almost everyone else uses the service, feels pointed and passive-aggressive. My friend (the Venter) has every right to be irritated by that. It chips away at you when someone repeatedly questions your choices, especially framing it as wasteful or extravagant.

But *damn*, calling her poor... that escalated things significantly. While my friend might see it as just stating a fact in response to being provoked ("she finds it expensive because she's poor"), that kind of bluntness, especially about finances, hits hard. It shifts the dynamic from her friend being annoying about laundry to my friend using a socioeconomic difference as a weapon in an argument. It sounds like she was fed up and lashed out, wanting to shut the comments down definitively. I get the impulse, maybe, after being poked repeatedly, but it’s still harsh and likely humiliating for the other person. It explains why the friend is "furious." That wasn't just about laundry anymore; it became personal and touched on a sensitive area.

I feel a bit conflicted. I want to support my friend because she came to me to vent, and the situation *is* annoying. But I also see that her response, while perhaps understandable in a moment of frustration, wasn't great and likely caused real hurt. It also makes me wonder about my friend's awareness of financial differences and how she navigates them. Saying "I'm not [poor], so I'll continue paying" sounds quite dismissive.

The question about whether to stay friends is telling. It suggests this isn't an isolated incident of annoyance, but maybe part of a pattern or a sign of deeper incompatibility. The fact she links the friend's behaviour to her having few friends suggests she's already judging the friend's character more broadly. She's clearly distancing herself emotionally. I need to be supportive without endorsing the name-calling, and help her process her feelings about the friendship itself, beyond just this incident. The "no lecture" request means I need to tread carefully and focus on validation and reflection rather than advice.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend (the one who sent the message) is primarily feeling **annoyed** and **judged**. The constant comments from her friend about the laundry service feel like persistent, unnecessary criticism of a personal choice that makes her life easier. She feels **frustrated** that this topic keeps coming up and that her friend seems "weirdly obsessed" with it. She likely perceives the comments ("How could anyone pay for that?", "What a waste of money") as intrusive and maybe even slightly envious or resentful.

She's also feeling **defensive**. Her repeated justification ("Why would I ever do something I don't want to...") shows she feels the need to defend her choice. When pushed again, her defensiveness escalated into **anger** and a desire to shut down the conversation forcefully. Calling her friend "poor" was likely motivated by a mix of this anger, a feeling of being provoked, and perhaps a touch of **contempt** or **superiority** stemming from the financial difference she perceives. She justifies this by framing it as a "fact," which suggests she might be feeling **righteous** in her anger, believing her friend's "fury" is an overreaction or misplaced because, in her view, she only spoke the truth.

Underneath, she might also be feeling a bit **confused** or **conflicted** about the friendship itself, which is why she's asking if she should continue it. The friend's behaviour makes her "like her less," indicating a growing **disconnection**. She's likely seeking **validation** from me – confirmation that her friend's behaviour is indeed weird and annoying, and perhaps tacit approval for her reaction, even though she says she doesn't want a lecture. She wants support and understanding for her frustration. Her motivation for messaging me is to vent these feelings, process the incident, and get perspective (even if she doesn't want direct advice) on the viability of the friendship.
# My response 
Ugh, that sounds incredibly annoying. Having someone constantly comment on a choice like that, especially one that makes your life easier and is common at your school, would get under anyone’s skin. It's totally understandable why you'd be frustrated – it sounds like she just wouldn't let it go, no matter how many times you explained your reasoning. That kind of persistent negativity about *your* choices can definitely wear you down and make you feel judged.

It sounds like things got really heated when she brought it up again. When you said she finds it expensive because she's poor, that clearly struck a nerve, given she's furious now. Those kinds of comments about money can escalate things fast, regardless of whether you feel it's factually true or not – finances are often a really sensitive spot for people.

It makes sense that her constant unwanted comments are making you like her less and even question the friendship. Friendships, especially in college when you're all figuring things out, can shift. Sometimes you realize the dynamic isn't working for you anymore, or that someone's negativity consistently brings you down. It's okay to reassess things.

Ultimately, only you can decide if this friendship is still right for you. Think about how you generally feel when you're around her, not just during these conflicts. Does she add value to your life overall? Do you feel respected (laundry comments aside)? Is this pattern of judgment something you see in other areas? There's no right or wrong answer, it's about what feels healthy and supportive *for you*. I'm here to listen whatever you decide or if you just need to vent more.
Gpt-4.1-mini

[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>
