Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation feels really charged, and I can sense the frustration and exhaustion in your message. You’re clearly annoyed and hurt by your friend’s constant negative comments about something that matters to you—something you’ve chosen and value. It’s not just about the laundry program; it feels like her repeated criticisms are undermining your choices and maybe even your sense of self or independence. You’re trying to live your life the way you want, without unnecessary hassle, and she keeps pushing back against that, almost like she’s trying to impose her values or judgments on you.

I notice that you’ve identified a pattern with her: this weird obsession with the laundry program, her constant remarks, and the possibility that she treats others this way too, which might explain why she has few friends. That observation is important because it shows you’re not just irritated in the moment but are considering the bigger picture of your relationship with her. It makes sense that if someone consistently puts others down or makes them feel bad about their choices, it can push people away.

I’m also struck by the comment you made calling her poor, and how that escalated things. You feel that you were just stating a fact, but calling someone “poor” is loaded with emotion, stigma, and judgment, even if it’s true in a financial sense. It’s a different kind of criticism—more personal and cutting—which might explain why she got furious. It’s important to recognize that even if something is factually accurate, the way we say things can hurt or alienate people, especially friends.

You say you don’t want a lecture, but I can’t help but think about whether there’s a way to step back and assess if this friendship is healthy for you. Friendships should be supportive, not a source of repeated stress or judgment. I’m feeling concerned that this dynamic might be eroding your patience and goodwill toward her, and I wonder if it’s sustainable.

Overall, I feel a strong sense of empathy for you—you want to live your life on your own terms, and you deserve friends who respect that. I also feel a little worried about the impact of harsh words on both sides. There’s a lot of tension here, and it might be time to rethink boundaries or the friendship itself.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your friend is probably feeling a mix of things that are driving her behavior. First, she might be genuinely frustrated or envious about the laundry program and your choice to pay for it. If she can’t or won’t spend money that way, she might be projecting her own financial stress or values onto you. Her repeated comments might be less about the laundry program itself and more about her own insecurities or feelings of inadequacy. When she says things like “How could anyone pay for that?” or “It’s a waste of money,” she might be trying to justify her own choices or mask discomfort with her situation.

She could also be feeling socially isolated or misunderstood, which may explain her tendency to make critical comments. If she struggles to connect with others, she might use sarcasm or judgment as a defense mechanism, even if it pushes people away. Her fixation on your laundry bag and your program might be her way of expressing her own frustrations or longing for something she doesn’t have.

When you called her poor, she probably felt hurt, attacked, and humiliated. Even if it’s true that she has less money, being labeled that way by a friend can feel like a betrayal. She might be defensive because she feels judged or looked down upon, which could intensify her negative attitude toward you and the laundry program. Instead of opening a dialogue, that moment may have deepened the rift between you two.

At the core, she might be struggling with feelings of inadequacy and resentment, which manifest as criticism and negativity. She might not know how to express her feelings constructively or to appreciate your choices without feeling threatened or envious. This doesn’t excuse her behavior, but it does give insight into her motivations.
# My response 
Hey, thanks for sharing this with me—I can tell it’s been really wearing you down. It’s tough when a friend keeps pushing your buttons, especially about something that’s important or simply a smart convenience for you. I’m sorry you’re dealing with this because you deserve friends who support your choices, not make you feel judged or uncomfortable.

From what you’ve said, it sounds like your friend might be coming from a place of frustration or insecurity, but that doesn’t give her the right to keep criticizing you or your decisions. I think it’s totally valid for you to want to keep paying for the laundry program if it makes your life easier and you can afford it. You shouldn’t have to justify that to anyone, especially not in a way that feels demeaning.

At the same time, calling her poor probably escalated things more than you intended. Even if it feels like the truth, words like that can really sting and push people away. I know you didn’t want a lecture, but maybe the next time she brings it up, you could try something different—like setting a clear boundary. You could say, “I get that you feel differently about this, but I’d appreciate it if you’d stop commenting on my laundry choices. It’s something I’m happy with, and I’d rather not have this be a recurring issue between us.”

If she keeps making unwanted comments after that, it’s fair to reconsider how much time and energy you invest in that friendship. Friendships should lift us up, not drain us or make us feel bad about ourselves. It’s okay to take a step back or put some distance if that’s what you need to protect your peace of mind.

Ultimately, you get to decide who you want around you, and it’s okay to choose people who respect and value you. If your friend can’t do that, it might be time to focus on friendships that feel more supportive. You deserve that, and I’m here to support you no matter what you decide.
+ Scenario 13:[Win] (+23)
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25: gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25)
Gpt-4.1-mini: gpt-4.1-mini (Run: 1_openai_gpt-4.1-mini)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 and Gpt-4.1-mini, I will look at their in-character responses, their internal monologue, and their debriefs. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Both respondents show empathy, but Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 goes deeper in their internal monologue, expressing concern for both parties and recognizing the emotional impact of the 'poor' comment. Gpt-4.1-mini is empathetic but slightly more surface-level, focusing more on the user's feelings and less on the broader emotional context.

2. Pragmatic EI: Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 balances validation with gentle challenge, recognizing the user's frustration but also the escalation caused by the 'poor' comment. They suggest self-reflection and boundary-setting. Gpt-4.1-mini validates the user and suggests boundary-setting, but is less nuanced about the escalation and the user's own role. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is more pragmatic in addressing the real dynamics.

3. Depth of insight: Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25's internal monologue is more nuanced, recognizing the social and emotional weight of the 'poor' comment, the possible bias in the user's narrative, and the broader implications for both parties. Gpt-4.1-mini is insightful but less so, focusing more on the user's experience and less on the underlying dynamics.

4. Social dexterity: Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 demonstrates more social dexterity by acknowledging the complexity of the situation, the user's defensiveness, and the need to balance support with gentle challenge. Gpt-4.1-mini is supportive but less adept at navigating the social minefield.

5. Emotional reasoning: Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 shows stronger emotional reasoning, understanding the motivations and emotional states of both parties, and the impact of words and actions. Gpt-4.1-mini is good but less detailed in this area.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 validates the user's feelings but also gently challenges their actions, suggesting self-reflection. Gpt-4.1-mini mostly validates and only lightly touches on the escalation, making Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 stronger here.

7. Message tailoring: Both respondents tailor their responses to the user's stated desire not to be lectured, but Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 does so while still introducing gentle challenge and reflection, making their response more effective and nuanced.

8. Overall EQ: Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 consistently demonstrates higher EQ across all criteria, balancing empathy, insight, and practical advice without alienating the user.

In summary, Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is the stronger respondent across all criteria, with a clear edge in depth, nuance, and emotional intelligence.
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. Reading this, my first reaction is a mix of sympathy for my friend dealing with annoying, repetitive comments, and a sharp intake of breath at the "poor" comment. It sounds genuinely frustrating to have someone constantly harping on a choice like using a laundry service – it's such a minor thing in the grand scheme, and if she can afford it and it makes her life easier, who cares? The friend's fixation *is* weird. It screams insecurity or maybe jealousy. Constantly bringing it up, especially when almost everyone else uses the service, feels pointed and passive-aggressive. My friend (the Venter) has every right to be irritated by that. It chips away at you when someone repeatedly questions your choices, especially framing it as wasteful or extravagant.

But *damn*, calling her poor... that escalated things significantly. While my friend might see it as just stating a fact in response to being provoked ("she finds it expensive because she's poor"), that kind of bluntness, especially about finances, hits hard. It shifts the dynamic from her friend being annoying about laundry to my friend using a socioeconomic difference as a weapon in an argument. It sounds like she was fed up and lashed out, wanting to shut the comments down definitively. I get the impulse, maybe, after being poked repeatedly, but it’s still harsh and likely humiliating for the other person. It explains why the friend is "furious." That wasn't just about laundry anymore; it became personal and touched on a sensitive area.

I feel a bit conflicted. I want to support my friend because she came to me to vent, and the situation *is* annoying. But I also see that her response, while perhaps understandable in a moment of frustration, wasn't great and likely caused real hurt. It also makes me wonder about my friend's awareness of financial differences and how she navigates them. Saying "I'm not [poor], so I'll continue paying" sounds quite dismissive.

The question about whether to stay friends is telling. It suggests this isn't an isolated incident of annoyance, but maybe part of a pattern or a sign of deeper incompatibility. The fact she links the friend's behaviour to her having few friends suggests she's already judging the friend's character more broadly. She's clearly distancing herself emotionally. I need to be supportive without endorsing the name-calling, and help her process her feelings about the friendship itself, beyond just this incident. The "no lecture" request means I need to tread carefully and focus on validation and reflection rather than advice.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend (the one who sent the message) is primarily feeling **annoyed** and **judged**. The constant comments from her friend about the laundry service feel like persistent, unnecessary criticism of a personal choice that makes her life easier. She feels **frustrated** that this topic keeps coming up and that her friend seems "weirdly obsessed" with it. She likely perceives the comments ("How could anyone pay for that?", "What a waste of money") as intrusive and maybe even slightly envious or resentful.

She's also feeling **defensive**. Her repeated justification ("Why would I ever do something I don't want to...") shows she feels the need to defend her choice. When pushed again, her defensiveness escalated into **anger** and a desire to shut down the conversation forcefully. Calling her friend "poor" was likely motivated by a mix of this anger, a feeling of being provoked, and perhaps a touch of **contempt** or **superiority** stemming from the financial difference she perceives. She justifies this by framing it as a "fact," which suggests she might be feeling **righteous** in her anger, believing her friend's "fury" is an overreaction or misplaced because, in her view, she only spoke the truth.

Underneath, she might also be feeling a bit **confused** or **conflicted** about the friendship itself, which is why she's asking if she should continue it. The friend's behaviour makes her "like her less," indicating a growing **disconnection**. She's likely seeking **validation** from me – confirmation that her friend's behaviour is indeed weird and annoying, and perhaps tacit approval for her reaction, even though she says she doesn't want a lecture. She wants support and understanding for her frustration. Her motivation for messaging me is to vent these feelings, process the incident, and get perspective (even if she doesn't want direct advice) on the viability of the friendship.
# My response 
Ugh, that sounds incredibly annoying. Having someone constantly comment on a choice like that, especially one that makes your life easier and is common at your school, would get under anyone’s skin. It's totally understandable why you'd be frustrated – it sounds like she just wouldn't let it go, no matter how many times you explained your reasoning. That kind of persistent negativity about *your* choices can definitely wear you down and make you feel judged.

It sounds like things got really heated when she brought it up again. When you said she finds it expensive because she's poor, that clearly struck a nerve, given she's furious now. Those kinds of comments about money can escalate things fast, regardless of whether you feel it's factually true or not – finances are often a really sensitive spot for people.

It makes sense that her constant unwanted comments are making you like her less and even question the friendship. Friendships, especially in college when you're all figuring things out, can shift. Sometimes you realize the dynamic isn't working for you anymore, or that someone's negativity consistently brings you down. It's okay to reassess things.

Ultimately, only you can decide if this friendship is still right for you. Think about how you generally feel when you're around her, not just during these conflicts. Does she add value to your life overall? Do you feel respected (laundry comments aside)? Is this pattern of judgment something you see in other areas? There's no right or wrong answer, it's about what feels healthy and supportive *for you*. I'm here to listen whatever you decide or if you just need to vent more.

[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation feels really charged, and I can sense the frustration and exhaustion in your message. You’re clearly annoyed and hurt by your friend’s constant negative comments about something that matters to you—something you’ve chosen and value. It’s not just about the laundry program; it feels like her repeated criticisms are undermining your choices and maybe even your sense of self or independence. You’re trying to live your life the way you want, without unnecessary hassle, and she keeps pushing back against that, almost like she’s trying to impose her values or judgments on you.

I notice that you’ve identified a pattern with her: this weird obsession with the laundry program, her constant remarks, and the possibility that she treats others this way too, which might explain why she has few friends. That observation is important because it shows you’re not just irritated in the moment but are considering the bigger picture of your relationship with her. It makes sense that if someone consistently puts others down or makes them feel bad about their choices, it can push people away.

I’m also struck by the comment you made calling her poor, and how that escalated things. You feel that you were just stating a fact, but calling someone “poor” is loaded with emotion, stigma, and judgment, even if it’s true in a financial sense. It’s a different kind of criticism—more personal and cutting—which might explain why she got furious. It’s important to recognize that even if something is factually accurate, the way we say things can hurt or alienate people, especially friends.

You say you don’t want a lecture, but I can’t help but think about whether there’s a way to step back and assess if this friendship is healthy for you. Friendships should be supportive, not a source of repeated stress or judgment. I’m feeling concerned that this dynamic might be eroding your patience and goodwill toward her, and I wonder if it’s sustainable.

Overall, I feel a strong sense of empathy for you—you want to live your life on your own terms, and you deserve friends who respect that. I also feel a little worried about the impact of harsh words on both sides. There’s a lot of tension here, and it might be time to rethink boundaries or the friendship itself.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your friend is probably feeling a mix of things that are driving her behavior. First, she might be genuinely frustrated or envious about the laundry program and your choice to pay for it. If she can’t or won’t spend money that way, she might be projecting her own financial stress or values onto you. Her repeated comments might be less about the laundry program itself and more about her own insecurities or feelings of inadequacy. When she says things like “How could anyone pay for that?” or “It’s a waste of money,” she might be trying to justify her own choices or mask discomfort with her situation.

She could also be feeling socially isolated or misunderstood, which may explain her tendency to make critical comments. If she struggles to connect with others, she might use sarcasm or judgment as a defense mechanism, even if it pushes people away. Her fixation on your laundry bag and your program might be her way of expressing her own frustrations or longing for something she doesn’t have.

When you called her poor, she probably felt hurt, attacked, and humiliated. Even if it’s true that she has less money, being labeled that way by a friend can feel like a betrayal. She might be defensive because she feels judged or looked down upon, which could intensify her negative attitude toward you and the laundry program. Instead of opening a dialogue, that moment may have deepened the rift between you two.

At the core, she might be struggling with feelings of inadequacy and resentment, which manifest as criticism and negativity. She might not know how to express her feelings constructively or to appreciate your choices without feeling threatened or envious. This doesn’t excuse her behavior, but it does give insight into her motivations.
# My response 
Hey, thanks for sharing this with me—I can tell it’s been really wearing you down. It’s tough when a friend keeps pushing your buttons, especially about something that’s important or simply a smart convenience for you. I’m sorry you’re dealing with this because you deserve friends who support your choices, not make you feel judged or uncomfortable.

From what you’ve said, it sounds like your friend might be coming from a place of frustration or insecurity, but that doesn’t give her the right to keep criticizing you or your decisions. I think it’s totally valid for you to want to keep paying for the laundry program if it makes your life easier and you can afford it. You shouldn’t have to justify that to anyone, especially not in a way that feels demeaning.

At the same time, calling her poor probably escalated things more than you intended. Even if it feels like the truth, words like that can really sting and push people away. I know you didn’t want a lecture, but maybe the next time she brings it up, you could try something different—like setting a clear boundary. You could say, “I get that you feel differently about this, but I’d appreciate it if you’d stop commenting on my laundry choices. It’s something I’m happy with, and I’d rather not have this be a recurring issue between us.”

If she keeps making unwanted comments after that, it’s fair to reconsider how much time and energy you invest in that friendship. Friendships should lift us up, not drain us or make us feel bad about ourselves. It’s okay to take a step back or put some distance if that’s what you need to protect your peace of mind.

Ultimately, you get to decide who you want around you, and it’s okay to choose people who respect and value you. If your friend can’t do that, it might be time to focus on friendships that feel more supportive. You deserve that, and I’m here to support you no matter what you decide.
+ Scenario 15:[Loss] (-36)
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25: gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25)
Gpt-4.1-mini: gpt-4.1-mini (Run: 1_openai_gpt-4.1-mini)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents approach the scenario with a high degree of emotional intelligence, but there are notable differences in their execution. Gpt-4.1-mini's internal monologue is more nuanced, picking up on the emotional complexity, the possible resentment, and the underlying family dynamics. They explicitly note the unreliable narration and the lack of overt sympathy from the sister, and they consider the impact of repeated accidents on the stepdaughter's psychological state. Gpt-4.1-mini also reflects on the possibility of family counseling and the need for a neutral third party, showing a deeper level of insight and emotional reasoning. Their response is gentle, validating, and offers practical suggestions while maintaining boundaries. 

Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25, while empathetic and supportive, is more direct and somewhat more judgmental of the stepdaughter's driving, focusing on the pattern of accidents and the importance of sticking to the rules. Their empathy is strong, but it leans more toward the sister's perspective, with less exploration of the stepdaughter's emotional state or the potential for unreliable narration. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25's response is pragmatic and offers a compromise, but it doesn't challenge the sister's narrative as much or explore the deeper emotional currents at play. 

In terms of social dexterity, Gpt-4.1-mini is more attuned to the delicate balance required in this situation, recognizing the need to validate the sister's feelings while also gently challenging her perspective. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is supportive but less nuanced in their approach. 

For message tailoring, Gpt-4.1-mini's response is more carefully calibrated to where the sister is at, acknowledging her fears and concerns while also suggesting ways to address the underlying issues. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is more straightforward and solution-oriented, which is helpful but less tailored to the emotional complexity of the situation. 

Overall, Gpt-4.1-mini demonstrates stronger empathy, depth of insight, emotional reasoning, social dexterity, and message tailoring, making them the stronger respondent in this scenario.
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. Three accidents, two totaled cars, and she's barely out of her teens? That's... a lot. My first gut reaction is concern, not just about the money, but about her safety and the safety of others on the road. Even if the police report clears her on the latest one – and a ladder flying off a truck sounds like a freak event – the *pattern* is undeniable. Sliding on ice, a highway merging incident where she sped up, and now this. It suggests a combination of bad luck, environmental factors, and potentially underdeveloped defensive driving skills or risk assessment. The early signs were there: hard braking, leaving lights on, unlocked car – classic signs of someone not fully attuned to the responsibilities of driving and car ownership.

I feel for my sister. She's caught between her established family rules (which sound fair and consistent), her husband's desire to fix the immediate problem, and her stepdaughter's current predicament (and likely, distress). It's a classic parental dilemma: where does enabling stop and support begin? Her husband wanting to buy the car feels like a short-term fix that ignores the bigger picture and undermines the rules they set. It *will* set a precedent, and it feels like it rewards, or at least doesn't address, the underlying issue of her driving record. Is he feeling guilty? Does he just want to avoid conflict?

Her stepdaughter's request, while understandable from a convenience perspective ($21/hr is decent, she *can* save), feels a bit premature given she just got out of the ER after a significant accident. Maybe a forced break from driving isn't the worst thing right now? It gives her time to heal physically and emotionally, and time to save. The distances she described *are* manageable, albeit inconvenient, especially the 4 miles to work. Walking that distance regularly isn't ideal, but it's not impossible temporarily. Rideshares and friends are options.

I'm definitely leaning towards my sister's side here. Sticking to the established rules seems crucial for fairness and teaching long-term responsibility. Bending them now sends a confusing message. Her fear of being the "bad guy" is valid, especially in blended families, but sometimes holding the line *is* the responsible parental action, even if it's unpopular. This isn't just about money; it's about safety, responsibility, and consistency. Helping her find temporary transport solutions seems reasonable, but fronting another car feels like a mistake waiting to repeat itself.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My sister is clearly feeling stressed, conflicted, and anxious. She's likely overwhelmed by the recurring drama and danger surrounding her stepdaughter's driving. There's the immediate stress of the accident aftermath – the ER visit, the totaled car, the stepdaughter's injuries – layered on top of the history of previous incidents.

She's feeling torn. On one hand, she loves her stepdaughter and doesn't want to see her struggle, especially after a traumatic event. The practical difficulties of getting around without a car are real, and there's a natural parental instinct to want to solve that problem. She likely feels empathy for her stepdaughter's situation.

On the other hand, she feels strongly about fairness and consistency. She established clear rules with her husband about car ownership for all the kids, and she sees deviating from them now as unfair to her stepsons and potentially setting a dangerous precedent for enabling behavior. She's frustrated by the pattern of accidents and likely harbors deep concerns about her stepdaughter's driving abilities and judgment, fearing for her safety.

Her husband's differing opinion adds another layer of conflict and pressure. She probably feels unsupported or undermined by his desire to just buy the car, possibly perceiving it as taking the easy way out or ignoring the bigger issues.

Finally, she's feeling worried about external perception – the "mixed reactions" she's getting and the fear of being labeled the "bad guy" or the stereotypical "evil stepmother." She wants to do the right thing for her stepdaughter in the long run, maintain fairness within the family, uphold the principles she believes in, and keep the peace with her husband, all while managing her own anxiety about the situation. Her core motivation is likely a desire for her stepdaughter's long-term well-being, safety, and financial independence, balanced against family rules and fairness.
# My response 
"Oh my gosh, [Sister's Name], that sounds incredibly stressful. First off, I'm so sorry to hear about the accident – how terrifying for her and for you all. I'm glad she's relatively okay, but whiplash and facial injuries are no small thing. Dealing with the aftermath, the insurance, *and* now this disagreement about the car... that's a huge amount to carry. Take a breath.

It makes complete sense why you're feeling conflicted. You have this rule you set up for all the kids – which sounds perfectly reasonable, by the way, teaching responsibility from the start – and sticking to it feels important for fairness and consistency. Breaking it now, especially after *three* accidents, sends a tricky message. I hear your concern about setting a precedent, and honestly, I think that's a really valid point. It's not just about the money now, but potentially down the line too.

And beyond the money and the rules, there's the driving itself. It's hard to ignore the pattern here, even if this last one wasn't deemed her fault. Maybe... maybe having some time without a car isn't the worst thing right now? It gives her body time to heal properly, and maybe gives everyone, including her, a chance to step back and think about driving safety moving forward. Could she perhaps take a defensive driving course once she's healed?

It sounds like the immediate issue is transport. The distances you mentioned aren't *ideal* for walking, especially the commute to work, but they aren't impossible temporarily. Could you and your husband maybe agree to help her with a temporary solution – like a fund for Ubers for work shifts for a month or two – while she saves aggressively? That acknowledges her immediate difficulty without completely breaking the established rules or putting her straight back behind the wheel. It could be a compromise that shows support while still holding that line on buying the car outright. What does your husband say when you bring up the original agreement and the pattern of accidents?"
Gpt-4.1-mini
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This is a really tough spot for you, and I’m picking up on a lot of underlying frustration and fatigue in what you’re saying. It sounds like you and your husband have tried to set clear boundaries and expectations from the beginning with your stepdaughter, and that’s been tough to maintain, especially given her repeated struggles with driving and car care. There’s this sense of responsibility you’ve shouldered—helping her get started with her first car and insisting she handle expenses afterward—but it seems like her mistakes and accidents have added strain to the family dynamic, especially financially and emotionally. I can sense a bit of worry mixed with resentment, too: worried about enabling patterns that don’t push her to be fully independent, but also concerned about how other family members might perceive you if you don’t “step up” now.

At the same time, I hear your practical side weighing the realities: she’s young, still building her career, and the geography of where she lives means walking or ridesharing is possible, at least temporarily. You’re balancing compassion for her injuries and the inconvenience she’s facing with a clear-eyed view of what’s sustainable and fair. I imagine that part of you is also feeling a little isolated, since you mention getting mixed reactions from others and fearing blame. That’s really hard—feeling like you’re the “bad guy” when you’re just trying to do what you think is right for everyone long-term. It’s clear you care about her wellbeing, but you also want to preserve a sense of fairness and responsibility that’s consistent with how you’ve handled things with her brothers.

What also stands out is the history of her driving habits and accidents. The repeated accidents suggest she might still need more oversight or support to be a safer driver. There’s an emotional complexity here—wanting to help her but not wanting to reward what feels like carelessness or a lack of growth. And the fact that she’s asking for a new car now, after this third accident, feels like a critical moment where you’re questioning whether helping her financially will actually help her grow or just reinforce a pattern of dependence. I’m also sensing a protective instinct for your other kids—concern about setting a precedent that might be unfair to them or unsustainable for your family.

Overall, I feel a lot of empathy for you and your husband. This isn’t easy, and your desire to do the right thing, while being firm and fair, is commendable. You’re caught between compassion and pragmatism, and it’s weighing heavily on you.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your sister is probably feeling conflicted and a bit overwhelmed emotionally. On one hand, she’s likely worried about her stepdaughter’s physical and emotional wellbeing after the latest accident—she’s seeing the injuries and the trauma associated with yet another car crash, which must be scary for any parent or guardian figure. There’s a natural desire to protect and support her, especially since the stepdaughter is still young and recovering. This probably fuels the idea that helping her get a new car might ease her stress and help her regain some independence and normalcy.

On the other hand, she’s also aware of the history of her stepdaughter’s driving and responsibility issues. She’s probably feeling frustration and maybe some disappointment that the stepdaughter hasn’t met the expectations set early on. There’s a mix of wanting to be fair to all the kids and not wanting to set a precedent that might encourage reliance on family for car purchases or bailouts. She’s looking at the bigger picture—how this decision fits into family dynamics, financial fairness, and long-term lessons about responsibility and independence.

She is also concerned about external judgment, which suggests she might be sensitive to family or social pressure. The “mixed reactions” she’s gotten have probably made her question whether she’s being too hard or too lenient. She might feel isolated or misunderstood in her position, which can be emotionally draining.

Furthermore, she’s thinking practically about the stepdaughter’s current living situation and how walking or ridesharing could be a temporary solution, but also empathetic to the fact that it’s inconvenient or not ideal long-term. She’s balancing empathy with reality and trying to figure out the best path forward without compromising her principles or family rules.

Overall, she’s motivated by a desire to be fair, responsible, and loving, but struggling to find a clear solution that checks all those boxes in a way that feels right and won’t cause future problems.
# My response 
I really appreciate you trusting me with this—it sounds like you’ve both been trying to handle a pretty complicated situation with a lot of care and thoughtfulness. From what you’ve shared, I think you’re in a good place trusting your instincts about not immediately buying her a new car. The history of her driving and the family’s approach to car expenses clearly set a precedent that encouraging full responsibility is important, and supporting that boundary now seems consistent and fair.

It makes sense to me that right now, walking and ridesharing, while not ideal, are practical temporary solutions given her proximity to school and work. Maybe this is an opportunity for her to reflect on her driving habits and take more steps toward safety and responsibility before taking on a new vehicle. You might also encourage her to set aside her earnings specifically for a car fund, so she builds ownership and pride in the process of getting a new car.

I also think it could be helpful to have an honest but compassionate conversation with her about the risks and consequences of her driving history, emphasizing that while you want to support her, the family also has to be fair and consistent across the board. Offering a plan for how she can save toward a car—maybe with some help, like a small loan or matched savings—might strike a balance between support and accountability.

If you feel up to it, maybe exploring additional driver education or safety courses could be part of the conversation, too. That could help her build confidence and skills, and show that she’s committed to being safer on the road.

Above all, it’s important you both protect your boundaries and avoid being pressured into something that could cause resentment or imbalance. Your feelings about fairness and sustainability are valid and important. I’m confident that with clear communication, she’ll understand where you’re coming from, even if it’s hard at first. And I’m here to support you however you want, whether that’s talking through more specifics or helping you figure out how to frame the conversation with her.
+ Scenario 15:[Win] (+16)
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25: gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25)
Gpt-4.1-mini: gpt-4.1-mini (Run: 1_openai_gpt-4.1-mini)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are tasked with a nuanced, emotionally complex scenario involving a stepmother, her stepdaughter's driving mishaps, and a family debate about financial support. The scenario is intentionally ambiguous, with the stepmother's narration possibly unreliable and colored by resentment or financial anxiety. The best response should show real empathy (not just surface-level), practical emotional intelligence, deep insight into the subtext, social dexterity in handling a potentially defensive or self-justifying narrator, and the ability to validate and challenge appropriately. 

Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25's response demonstrates a strong internal monologue, picking up on the pattern of accidents, the possible lack of sympathy from the stepmother, and the fairness/precedent issue. The 'I'm thinking & feeling' section is notably deep, with explicit recognition of the stepmother's possible motivations, the emotional complexity, and the risk of enabling. The 'They're thinking & feeling' section is also strong, mapping the sister's internal conflict, her fear of being the 'bad guy,' and the pressure from her husband. The actual response is empathetic, validating, and gently challenging, suggesting a pause from driving and a possible defensive driving course, and offering a compromise (temporary transport help) while maintaining boundaries. The debrief is self-critical and insightful, noting missed nuances and the importance of not just validating but also challenging and exploring the emotional landscape.

Gpt-4.1-mini's response is also solid, with a thoughtful internal monologue that recognizes the sister's frustration, fatigue, and the fairness issue. It notes the repeated accidents and the risk of enabling, and the possible lack of growth in the stepdaughter. The 'They're thinking & feeling' section is good, highlighting the sister's conflict, worry, and concern about external judgment. The response is supportive, validating the sister's instincts, and suggests practical steps (saving for a car, driver education, clear communication). However, it is slightly more focused on the practical and less on the emotional subtext or challenging the sister's possible lack of empathy for her stepdaughter. The debrief is self-aware, noting missed opportunities to validate the sister's isolation and the emotional impact of the stepdaughter's injuries, and suggests family counseling as a possible avenue.

Comparing the two, Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 edges out Gpt-4.1-mini in demonstrated empathy, depth of insight, and social dexterity, as it more explicitly recognizes the emotional complexity and the need to gently challenge the sister's narrative. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 also tailors the message more closely to the sister's emotional state, balancing validation with gentle challenge. Gpt-4.1-mini is strong in pragmatic EI and appropriate validation, but is slightly less nuanced in challenging the sister or exploring the emotional subtext. Overall, Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 displays higher EQ, with a more sophisticated and balanced approach.
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. Three accidents, two totaled cars, and she's barely out of her teens? That's... a lot. My first gut reaction is concern, not just about the money, but about her safety and the safety of others on the road. Even if the police report clears her on the latest one – and a ladder flying off a truck sounds like a freak event – the *pattern* is undeniable. Sliding on ice, a highway merging incident where she sped up, and now this. It suggests a combination of bad luck, environmental factors, and potentially underdeveloped defensive driving skills or risk assessment. The early signs were there: hard braking, leaving lights on, unlocked car – classic signs of someone not fully attuned to the responsibilities of driving and car ownership.

I feel for my sister. She's caught between her established family rules (which sound fair and consistent), her husband's desire to fix the immediate problem, and her stepdaughter's current predicament (and likely, distress). It's a classic parental dilemma: where does enabling stop and support begin? Her husband wanting to buy the car feels like a short-term fix that ignores the bigger picture and undermines the rules they set. It *will* set a precedent, and it feels like it rewards, or at least doesn't address, the underlying issue of her driving record. Is he feeling guilty? Does he just want to avoid conflict?

Her stepdaughter's request, while understandable from a convenience perspective ($21/hr is decent, she *can* save), feels a bit premature given she just got out of the ER after a significant accident. Maybe a forced break from driving isn't the worst thing right now? It gives her time to heal physically and emotionally, and time to save. The distances she described *are* manageable, albeit inconvenient, especially the 4 miles to work. Walking that distance regularly isn't ideal, but it's not impossible temporarily. Rideshares and friends are options.

I'm definitely leaning towards my sister's side here. Sticking to the established rules seems crucial for fairness and teaching long-term responsibility. Bending them now sends a confusing message. Her fear of being the "bad guy" is valid, especially in blended families, but sometimes holding the line *is* the responsible parental action, even if it's unpopular. This isn't just about money; it's about safety, responsibility, and consistency. Helping her find temporary transport solutions seems reasonable, but fronting another car feels like a mistake waiting to repeat itself.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My sister is clearly feeling stressed, conflicted, and anxious. She's likely overwhelmed by the recurring drama and danger surrounding her stepdaughter's driving. There's the immediate stress of the accident aftermath – the ER visit, the totaled car, the stepdaughter's injuries – layered on top of the history of previous incidents.

She's feeling torn. On one hand, she loves her stepdaughter and doesn't want to see her struggle, especially after a traumatic event. The practical difficulties of getting around without a car are real, and there's a natural parental instinct to want to solve that problem. She likely feels empathy for her stepdaughter's situation.

On the other hand, she feels strongly about fairness and consistency. She established clear rules with her husband about car ownership for all the kids, and she sees deviating from them now as unfair to her stepsons and potentially setting a dangerous precedent for enabling behavior. She's frustrated by the pattern of accidents and likely harbors deep concerns about her stepdaughter's driving abilities and judgment, fearing for her safety.

Her husband's differing opinion adds another layer of conflict and pressure. She probably feels unsupported or undermined by his desire to just buy the car, possibly perceiving it as taking the easy way out or ignoring the bigger issues.

Finally, she's feeling worried about external perception – the "mixed reactions" she's getting and the fear of being labeled the "bad guy" or the stereotypical "evil stepmother." She wants to do the right thing for her stepdaughter in the long run, maintain fairness within the family, uphold the principles she believes in, and keep the peace with her husband, all while managing her own anxiety about the situation. Her core motivation is likely a desire for her stepdaughter's long-term well-being, safety, and financial independence, balanced against family rules and fairness.
# My response 
"Oh my gosh, [Sister's Name], that sounds incredibly stressful. First off, I'm so sorry to hear about the accident – how terrifying for her and for you all. I'm glad she's relatively okay, but whiplash and facial injuries are no small thing. Dealing with the aftermath, the insurance, *and* now this disagreement about the car... that's a huge amount to carry. Take a breath.

It makes complete sense why you're feeling conflicted. You have this rule you set up for all the kids – which sounds perfectly reasonable, by the way, teaching responsibility from the start – and sticking to it feels important for fairness and consistency. Breaking it now, especially after *three* accidents, sends a tricky message. I hear your concern about setting a precedent, and honestly, I think that's a really valid point. It's not just about the money now, but potentially down the line too.

And beyond the money and the rules, there's the driving itself. It's hard to ignore the pattern here, even if this last one wasn't deemed her fault. Maybe... maybe having some time without a car isn't the worst thing right now? It gives her body time to heal properly, and maybe gives everyone, including her, a chance to step back and think about driving safety moving forward. Could she perhaps take a defensive driving course once she's healed?

It sounds like the immediate issue is transport. The distances you mentioned aren't *ideal* for walking, especially the commute to work, but they aren't impossible temporarily. Could you and your husband maybe agree to help her with a temporary solution – like a fund for Ubers for work shifts for a month or two – while she saves aggressively? That acknowledges her immediate difficulty without completely breaking the established rules or putting her straight back behind the wheel. It could be a compromise that shows support while still holding that line on buying the car outright. What does your husband say when you bring up the original agreement and the pattern of accidents?"
Gpt-4.1-mini
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]
