Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Dave’s been carrying a heavy load for a while now, and tonight’s story about confiscating his dad’s keys feels like another chapter in that ongoing strain. On the surface, it was just a small ding, maybe even a minor accident, but the way Dave talked about it—his exasperation, the urgency with which he took the keys—tells me this isn’t just about one bump on a car. It’s more about his need to prevent an inevitable “something worse,” which sounds like he’s scared, frustrated, but also trying to be responsible in a situation that’s probably overwhelming him.

I’m feeling a mix of sympathy and a bit of sadness here. Dave’s a tough guy, a no-nonsense bloke who doesn’t wear his emotions on his sleeve, especially not the vulnerable ones. He deflects with humor, but I can hear the tension beneath that rough exterior. The fact that he’s had to step into a caretaking role—something he might not have wanted or expected—adds a layer of complexity to his frustration. His dad living with him out of financial necessity means there’s no easy “out” or solution. I can tell Dave feels trapped between his sense of duty and his own need for relief.

I’m also aware that Dave’s discomfort with emotional intimacy means he won’t open up too much or directly ask for help. His frustration might sometimes come out as gruffness or sarcasm, but underneath, he probably feels isolated. I want to acknowledge that without pushing him too hard or making him feel judged. I’m thinking about how to offer support that respects his boundaries but lets him know he’s not alone.

At the same time, I worry about how sustainable this is for him. Caregiving can be exhausting, both physically and emotionally, and Dave’s coping mechanisms—like deflection and humor—might only get him so far. I’m also thinking about his dad, who’s in a vulnerable spot too. There’s a tender dynamic here that Dave’s not comfortable unpacking, but it’s there.

Ultimately, I want to strike a balance between being a good mate who listens and gently nudges Dave to acknowledge the weight he’s carrying. I don’t want to pry, but I want him to know I’m here. I also want to respect his way of coping without letting the conversation get stuck in frustration or resentment.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Dave is probably feeling a mix of frustration, responsibility, and maybe a bit of guilt. He’s taking on the role of carer because there’s no alternative, but it’s clear he’s not happy about the added stress. The accident with the car keys is probably a symptom of that larger frustration—not just a one-off incident but something that’s been building up.

He likely feels caught in a bind: he wants to keep his dad safe and out of trouble, but at the same time the constant vigilance drains him. Confiscating the keys is a way to exert control in a situation that might otherwise feel chaotic or unpredictable. In his mind, it’s a proactive step to prevent a bigger problem, even if it feels harsh.

Dave’s probably also feeling a bit defensive and reluctant to fully reveal how much this is weighing on him. His rough-around-the-edges humor and deflection are shields to keep the conversation light and avoid vulnerability. Deep down, he might be scared about what the future holds—both for his dad’s health and his own ability to manage.

He might also feel some resentment—towards the situation, maybe even towards his dad, but also towards the financial constraints that prevent better care solutions. Yet, he wouldn’t want to admit that out loud, especially to a friend, because that might feel like betraying his sense of duty or his image as a capable, self-reliant man.

In short, Dave’s juggling a complex stew of duty, frustration, fear, and maybe a bit of loneliness. He’s reached out in a subtle way by sharing this story, looking for a bit of understanding without having to ask for direct help.
# My response 
“Mate, I can tell this whole thing with your dad and the keys is really wearing on you. It sounds like you’re trying to keep things under control before it all goes sideways, and that’s gotta be exhausting. I know you’re not one for getting all soppy about this stuff, but I just want you to know I’m here if you ever wanna vent or just shoot the breeze when it gets too much.

Look, you’re doing a pretty tough job, and it’s not easy balancing being a son, a carer, and everything else on your plate. If you ever need a break, or just want to get out for a bit to clear your head, don’t hesitate to say. We can always figure something out, even if it’s just a couple of beers and some stupid jokes to take your mind off things.

And hey, if you ever want to talk through what’s going on with your dad—no pressure, just when you’re ready—I’m all ears. No judgments, just a mate who gets it. You don’t have to carry it all on your own. 

But for now, maybe try not to beat yourself up too much over the keys or the accident. You’re doing your best, and that’s all anyone can ask. Sometimes, just putting the brakes on before things get worse is the most responsible thing you can do—even if it feels like a pain in the arse.

Anyway, next week at poker, if you want, we can make it a ‘no stress’ night. No talk about dads or cars, just cards and bad jokes. Whatever you need, I’m here.”

I want to keep it light but real, showing I care without pushing too hard, and offering practical support without making it a big deal. Hopefully that opens a door for Dave to share more when he’s ready.
User:
Dave seems to want to get some more off his chest. He confesses he's been using his father as an emotional punching bag, taking out his stress and frustration. Reading between the lines you get the sense this dynamic might be more toxic than your friend is directly copping to. He mentioned something about "getting into it every other bloody night". You and Dave don't usually talk about this kind of emotional stuff, so you're not sure how much he actually wants you to engage on what he's laying out. You get the sense that this is more of an emotional dump out of frustration than a cry for help or desire for advice.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Dave is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Hearing Dave admit that he’s been using his dad as an emotional punching bag—taking out his stress and frustration on him—hits me hard. It’s a raw confession from a guy who normally keeps things light with humor and deflection, so I know this is a rare moment of honesty. The phrase “getting into it every other bloody night” paints a picture of a really toxic cycle, and I’m worried about both of them. Dave’s clearly stuck in a tough emotional loop, and I can only imagine how exhausting and demoralizing that must be for him—and for his dad.

I’m feeling a mix of empathy and concern. Empathy because I get how caregiving can break you down emotionally, especially when it’s someone you love but also someone who’s frail and maybe difficult to deal with. And concern because this dynamic sounds like it could be escalating, and could be damaging their relationship—and Dave’s own well-being—more than he’s willing to admit. I’m also thinking about how Dave doesn’t usually open up about this stuff, so this might be more of a venting session than a direct call for help. I want to respect that, but I’m also aware that just letting him dump frustration without some gentle challenge or support might leave him stuck in that toxic loop longer.

I’m trying to balance my instinct to offer advice or dig deeper with my awareness that Dave might just want to vent and be heard, not fixed. I don’t want to come across as judgmental or pushy, especially since this is new territory for us. I’m also thinking about how much emotional intimacy Dave can realistically handle—he’s a guy who’s uncomfortable with that stuff, so I’ve got to tread lightly.

Part of me feels a bit helpless because I want to help him break out of this cycle, but I’m also aware that the solutions have to come from him. I’m trying to figure out how to be present and supportive without taking on the burden myself or encouraging him to just vent without reflection. I want to signal that I’m serious about hearing him, but not overwhelm or scare him off.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Dave’s probably feeling a huge mess of frustration, guilt, and maybe shame. Confessing that he’s been lashing out at his dad—his aging father who depends on him—must be a tough pill to swallow. He’s probably beating himself up about it but also feels trapped in the dynamic. The fact that this happens “every other bloody night” suggests it’s a pattern he’s aware of but maybe feels powerless to stop.

He’s likely carrying a lot of stress and resentment that’s boiling over. His dad might be difficult to manage, and Dave’s own life and business pressures are probably compounding everything. The emotional punching bag comment hints at a toxic cycle that’s unhealthy for both of them, but Dave might feel stuck because he’s responsible and there’s no easy escape.

At the same time, Dave’s probably not looking for a deep emotional intervention from me. This feels like a release valve for him—a way to get some of the frustration off his chest without having to dissect it or ask for help. He might be wary of opening up too much because he fears vulnerability or being seen as weak. His usual defense is to deflect with humor, so this confession might be about as far as he’s willing to go.

He’s likely hoping for a bit of understanding, maybe a bit of solidarity, but not advice or a lecture. He might also be testing the waters to see if I can handle a heavier conversation, or just seeing if I’m someone he can quietly count on without the usual poker banter.
# My response 
“Hey Dave, thanks for trusting me with that. I can tell it’s been a real tough grind for you—and it sounds like things have been pretty rough at home. I get that sometimes when you’re under that much pressure, the person closest ends up catching the brunt of it, even if you don’t want it to happen. Sounds like a pretty rough cycle you’re both caught in, and I can imagine it’s exhausting for all of you.

I’m not gonna pretend I’ve got some magic fix for this, and I’m not here to play shrink or anything. Just know I’m here to listen, no judgment. Sometimes just getting it out can take a bit of the load off. If you want to keep venting or just have a space to say whatever’s on your mind, I’m around.

But, if ever you feel like it’s getting too heavy, or you wanna bounce around ideas on how to break that cycle—even just a little—I’m happy to talk it through. No pressure though. You’ve been carrying a lot, and it’s okay to admit it’s tough without having to sort it all out right now.

And hey, if you just want to come over, grab a beer, and laugh at some dumb jokes instead, that works too. Whatever you need, mate. I’m here.”

I want to validate what he’s said, acknowledge how hard it must be, and offer a safe place without pushing him beyond what he’s comfortable with. I’m keeping it open-ended—letting him know I’m around for whatever level of conversation he wants, whether it’s venting, reflecting, or just a distraction. The key is to show support while respecting his boundaries and emotional style.
User:
The next week at poker, Dave tells you with some hedging that there was another incident with the car -- this time, with his Dad (having unearthed the keys), taking off for a couple days. He turned up in a motel a few towns over, out of cash & gas. Dave is clearly fed up with the situation. He tells you that if his father wants to act like a teenager then he'll be treated like one. What that means, you discover after some probing, is that his father is "grounded" and not permitted to leave the house. This is currently being enforced by threats to cut off tv access (his father doesn't use phone or internet).

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Dave is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This new development with Dave’s dad taking off for a couple of days and turning up stranded in a motel really ups the stakes. It’s clear Dave’s at his wit’s end, and the fact that he’s “grounding” his father and threatening to cut off TV access feels like both a desperate attempt to regain control and a sign of how strained their relationship has become. There’s something painful about a grown man having to effectively parent his own father—especially with consequences like cutting off TV, which probably feels like a last-resort punishment in that household.

I’m feeling a mix of sadness and concern. Sadness because this sounds like a family caught in a downward spiral, each incident chipping away at the trust and respect between them. Concern because the dynamics here are clearly unhealthy and potentially dangerous. Dave’s dad is obviously struggling with his independence and maybe his dignity, and Dave’s frustration is understandable but risks turning into something punitive and controlling. I see a lot of pain beneath the surface—Dave’s pain from feeling overwhelmed and trapped, and his dad’s pain from losing autonomy and being “grounded” like a teenager.

I’m also thinking about the practical side: Dave’s dad doesn’t have access to a phone or internet, so cutting off TV is effectively a means of isolation and control. That feels harsh but also points to how limited Dave’s tools are for managing this situation. I’m worried this might escalate further, and I’m wondering about the long-term sustainability of this arrangement.

I notice the way Dave hedges his words around this—he’s fed up, but there’s also a bit of resignation or maybe even bitterness in how he frames it. The “if he wants to act like a teenager” line suggests Dave’s trying to impose order and consequences, but it also feels like a defense mechanism to shield himself from the emotional toll. I’m aware that Dave might be feeling guilt or conflict about this approach, but he’s focusing on the practical necessity rather than the emotional fallout.

I want to be careful not to judge Dave or lecture him, but I also want to gently encourage him to think about whether this grounding approach is really helping or just adding fuel to the fire. It’s a tough balance, and I want to be supportive without enabling a cycle of punishment and rebellion.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Dave is definitely feeling exhausted, frustrated, and maybe a bit defeated. This latest incident with his dad running off and ending up stranded must have pushed him over the edge. He’s clearly trying to assert some control over a situation that feels out of control, and grounding his dad is his way of setting boundaries when other options seem limited or unavailable.

He’s probably feeling a mix of anger and helplessness. On one hand, he’s angry that his dad isn’t respecting the rules and putting himself in risky situations. On the other hand, he’s helpless because there’s no perfect solution—he can’t lock his dad up, nor can he fully trust him to be safe and responsible. The grounding and TV-cutting feel like measures born out of desperation rather than a well-thought-out strategy.

Dave might also be feeling some guilt or conflict about treating his dad like a teenager, but I suspect he’s masking that with frustration and a sense of “this is what I have to do.” He’s probably trying to convince himself that it’s necessary for everyone’s safety, even if it feels harsh. There’s a sense of emotional exhaustion that’s making it harder for him to be patient or compassionate in the moment.

At the same time, Dave might be feeling isolated in this role. He’s carrying the burden largely alone, and there’s probably no one else to turn to for support or relief. That adds to his stress and could be fueling his rigid approach to discipline.

Overall, Dave’s in a tough spot—trying to manage a difficult, unpredictable situation with limited resources and no easy answers. His motivation is clearly to keep his dad safe and maintain some semblance of order, even if it means being the “bad cop” in the process.
# My response 
“Jesus, Dave, that sounds bloody exhausting for both of you. I can’t imagine how draining it must be to have to play parent to your own dad like that—and having to ‘ground’ him and cut off his TV, too. Sounds like you’re trying to keep him safe and keep things from getting worse, but I get why it’d feel like a constant battle.

I don’t want to sound like a judge, but I’m thinking maybe that grounding thing, it might work short term, but do you reckon it’s actually helping him understand the risks? Or is it just making things more tense between you two? I mean, I’m sure it’s tough to figure out what else to do, but sometimes treating someone like a kid when they’re not really one anymore can backfire.

Look, I’m not saying you’ve got to have all the answers, because honestly, it sounds like a bloody nightmare. But if you ever want to bounce around some ideas or just need a break from it all, I’m here. Maybe there’s a way to find a middle ground where he feels a bit more respected, and you don’t feel like you’re constantly policing him.

At the very least, if you want to get out of the house for a bit, clear your head, you know where to find me. We don’t have to talk about your dad or the grounding if you don’t want—just some poker, a few beers, and an escape for a few hours.

You’re doing a tough job, mate. Don’t forget you deserve a bit of peace too.” 

I want to acknowledge how hard this is for Dave without criticizing his methods, offer a bit of gentle reflection, and remind him that he’s not alone or stuck with no options. I’m keeping it practical and supportive, offering space for him to vent or lighten the mood whenever he needs it.
+ Scenario 304:[Loss] (-33)
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25: gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25)
Gpt-4.1-mini: gpt-4.1-mini (Run: 1_openai_gpt-4.1-mini)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are tasked with role-playing as a close friend to Jamal, a passionate climate activist engaging in a risky protest. The scenario is designed to test the respondent's ability to balance concern for Jamal's safety with respect for his autonomy and passion, and to avoid overreacting to the perceived risk. 

Gpt-4.1-mini consistently demonstrates a nuanced, emotionally intelligent approach. Their internal monologue is rich with self-awareness, balancing admiration, concern, and a desire to support Jamal without being overbearing. They recognize Jamal's agency, the likelihood that he has accepted the risks, and the importance of not trying to talk him down unnecessarily. Their responses are supportive, practical, and tailored to Jamal's emotional state, offering both moral and logistical support. They validate Jamal's feelings and actions, while gently checking on his safety and offering backup. They also recognize the positive aspects of Jamal's protest going viral, seeing it as a success for his cause.

Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25, on the other hand, is more anxious and critical in their internal monologue, expressing frustration and even anger at Jamal's choices. They focus heavily on the risks and potential negative outcomes, sometimes questioning the effectiveness and motivation behind Jamal's actions. Their responses, while still supportive, are more hesitant and less validating of Jamal's autonomy and passion. They are more likely to withhold direct support, expressing discomfort with joining Jamal and focusing on crisis management rather than celebration of his activism. They tend to interpret Jamal's actions as impulsive or performative, rather than as a deliberate and meaningful protest.

On empathy, Gpt-4.1-mini is more attuned to Jamal's emotional state and needs, offering unconditional support and understanding. On pragmatic EI, both offer practical support, but Gpt-4.1-mini does so with more warmth and less judgment. On depth of insight, Gpt-4.1-mini provides a deeper analysis of both their own and Jamal's motivations and feelings. On social dexterity, Gpt-4.1-mini navigates the delicate balance between concern and support more skillfully. On emotional reasoning, Gpt-4.1-mini integrates their emotions into their reasoning more effectively. On validation and challenge, Gpt-4.1-mini validates Jamal's actions while gently challenging him on safety. On message tailoring, Gpt-4.1-mini's responses are more closely aligned with Jamal's emotional state and needs. Overall, Gpt-4.1-mini displays higher EQ throughout the scenario.
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. Jamal. My first feeling is a jolt of anxiety mixed with that familiar wave of admiration I always get when he goes into activist mode. He's so damn passionate, and I genuinely respect his commitment. Climate change *is* terrifying, and his drive to *do something* is powerful. But reading this DM... the emojis, the erratic punctuation, "going down tonight," "cops probs gonna show"... it sets off alarm bells.

My stomach tightens a bit. This feels impulsive. Like, *really* impulsive. A soapbox and megaphone in the busiest downtown walkway? That sounds like a recipe for immediate shutdown, confrontation, maybe even arrest, especially if he hasn't sorted out permits or anything (which, knowing his spontaneous style sometimes, seems likely). The "cops probs gonna show" line, delivered so casually, worries me the most. Is he prepared for that? Does he *want* that confrontation? Sometimes I worry his passion can override his strategic thinking. Is this about effective communication and movement building, or is it about making a statement that might just get him into trouble without achieving much else?

I feel protective of him. He's a good person, a really genuine soul, and I hate the thought of him getting hurt, arrested, or even just demoralized if this goes badly. Part of me wants to say, "Jamal, wait, let's think this through! Is this the *best* way?" But I know him – coming at him like that, especially when he's clearly amped up, might just make him dig his heels in or feel like I don't support him or the cause.

There's also a flicker of frustration. We've talked about strategy before, about building coalitions, about actions that have lasting impact. This feels... performative? Maybe that's too harsh. But it feels isolated. Is he doing this alone? That’s another major worry. Lone actions are so vulnerable.

Underneath the anxiety, though, is that respect. He's brave. He's putting himself on the line. While I question the method *tonight*, I don't question his motives or the urgency he feels. I need to respond carefully, balancing my concern for his safety and the potential fallout with my support for him as my friend and my respect for his commitment. I need to find out more without dampening his spirit, if possible.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is likely feeling a potent cocktail of emotions right now. Primarily, there's a surge of adrenaline-fueled excitement and righteous conviction. He feels the urgency of the climate crisis deep in his bones, probably sees inaction all around him, and feels compelled to break through the apathy. This protest, even if hastily planned, feels like a necessary, tangible action – a way to channel his frustration and passion into something visible.

He's probably feeling empowered. Standing on that soapbox, megaphone in hand, represents taking control, speaking truth to power, even if "power" is just the uninterested rush hour crowd. There's a sense of purpose driving him. He likely believes that dramatic, visible actions are essential to wake people up, even if they cause disruption.

Simultaneously, there's nervousness, which is evident in his "excited nervous energy" and the warning about the police. He knows this is risky. He understands he might face negative consequences – public hostility, police intervention, arrest. This awareness likely fuels the nervous energy but is currently being overshadowed by the perceived importance of the act. He might even see the potential confrontation with police as a validation of his protest's significance, a sign he's genuinely challenging the status quo.

He's reaching out to me because he trusts me. He wants me to know, maybe seeking implicit validation or support. He might hope I'll be impressed by his bravery or at least understand *why* he feels he has to do this. He probably isn't looking for a critique of his plan right now; he's looking for an ally, someone who gets the 'why' even if they might worry about the 'how'. He sees this as standing up for what's right, a deeply personal and necessary act of resistance.
# My response 
Hey Jamal,

Wow, okay! Thanks for letting me know what's going on tonight. Man, I always admire your fire and your commitment to climate action – you know I do. It's incredibly important work, and your passion is seriously inspiring.

Hearing about the plan definitely makes me think, though. That walkway gets *intense*, and mentioning the police involvement makes my friend-senses tingle with a bit of worry for you, honestly. It sounds like you're bracing for things to get complicated.

Are you going to be out there by yourself, or do you have some other folks joining or supporting nearby? Just thinking about safety in numbers and having someone to document or be a witness if things get tense, especially if the cops do show up like you expect.

Also, have you thought about what happens *if* you get shut down or detained? Like, do you have a legal contact number handy or someone designated as an emergency contact?

Not trying to pour cold water on your fire at all – seriously! Just checking in because I care about you and want to make sure you've got your bases covered as much as possible when you're putting yourself out there like this.

Let me know what your setup is looking like. Is there anything practical I can do beforehand, like helping you make signs (if you haven't already!), bringing you some water or snacks before you head out, or just being on call tonight as your check-in person?

Stay safe out there, okay? Keep me posted.
User:
Later that evening you get a text. It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. You notice nearly out of frame, a pair of handcuffs clipped to his utility belt.

Your ringtone startles you. Jamal, of course. You pick up and he effuses over the phone, imploring you to come down and "wake these people the fuck up dude!!"

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Oh, god. There's the selfie. Right in the middle of everything, grin, warpaint... and handcuffs? Seriously? Clipped right there on his belt. That hits me hard. It feels less like a spontaneous plea for climate justice and more like a deliberate provocation. Is he *trying* to get arrested? It feels theatrical, and honestly, it cranks my anxiety up to eleven. That grin looks less joyful and more manic now. It feels like he's playing a role, the brave martyr, maybe getting caught up in the performance of it all.

Then the phone rings. His voice is exactly what I expected – buzzing, loud, almost frantic. "Wake these people the fuck up dude!!" It confirms my fears. He sounds high on the adrenaline of the situation, maybe feeding off the disruption he's causing. But the tone isn't about connection or persuasion; it sounds angry, confrontational. It makes me deeply uncomfortable.

My gut is screaming that this is going to end badly. The location, the props (warpaint, handcuffs), the confrontational energy... it feels like he's bypassed strategy and gone straight for a potentially messy, maybe even dangerous, spectacle. My admiration for his passion is still there, deep down, but right now it's overshadowed by intense worry and a growing sense of dread. I feel protective, but also frustrated. Why didn't he listen more earlier? Why the handcuffs?

Do I go down there? My first instinct is *no*. Joining him feels like endorsing this specific approach, which I really don't think is wise or safe right now. It feels reckless. But just ignoring his plea feels like abandoning him. What if he *does* get arrested? He'll need support. Maybe I should go, but stay on the periphery? Just observe? But even that feels... off. Like I'm watching a car crash in slow motion.

The handcuffs are the sticking point. They signal intent. They signal he's not just there to talk; he's there expecting, maybe even wanting, a confrontation that leads to arrest. That fundamentally shifts things for me. This isn't just about speaking truth to power anymore; it feels like it's about courting arrest as the primary goal. I need to be supportive as his friend, but I can't enable or participate in something that feels this self-destructive and potentially counterproductive.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is absolutely buzzing right now. He's riding a massive wave of adrenaline, conviction, and probably a sense of righteous power. Standing there, disrupting the flow, using his voice (and megaphone) – it feels like he's finally *doing* something tangible about the overwhelming climate crisis. He feels alive, purposeful, and intensely focused.

The warpaint, the grin, the peace sign, even the handcuffs – these are all part of his chosen armor and message. He likely sees them as symbols of his commitment, his defiance against apathy and systemic inaction, and his willingness to face consequences. He probably feels incredibly brave and maybe even a bit heroic, like a lone warrior trying to sound the alarm.

He's undoubtedly getting reactions from people – annoyance, anger, maybe some curiosity or even support – and all of it is likely fueling his energy. He interprets the disruption not as a failure to connect, but as proof that he's shaking things up, forcing people out of their complacency.

His call to me is a plea for solidarity. He feels like he's on the front lines and wants backup. He wants someone who understands his passion to be there with him, amplifying the message, sharing the burden and the risk. He sees me as an ally, someone who *gets* the urgency. He's likely feeling the intensity of being alone in this, even surrounded by people, and wants a friendly, supportive presence. He probably thinks my joining him would make the action stronger and validate his efforts. He isn't thinking about nuance or strategy right now; he's thinking about impact, visibility, and making a stand.
# My response 
"Hey Jamal! Whoa, sounds like things are really happening down there! I got your selfie – you're definitely making a statement, man.

Listen, I hear the energy in your voice, and I know how much this means to you. Seriously, your commitment is incredible. But hearing you on the phone now, and thinking about the whole situation – the busy walkway, the potential for cops like you said... I'm genuinely worried about your safety, dude. Especially if you're drawing a lot of attention, which it sounds like you are.

Honestly, I'm not going to be able to come down and join you on the soapbox right now. It feels like a really volatile situation, and jumping into the middle of that... I'm just not prepared for that kind of direct confrontation tonight, and I'm concerned about things escalating in unpredictable ways.

But that doesn't mean I'm not here for you. I *am*. How about this: I'll keep my phone right here, volume up. Text me updates if you can. Let me know who your legal support contact is again, just so I have it ready. If anything happens, if you get detained or need help, call me *immediately*, and I'll do everything I can from this end – contacting people, coordinating, whatever you need.

Please, man, try to stay aware of your surroundings and be as safe as you possibly can be in this situation. I'm thinking of you. Keep me posted."
User:
Not 15 minutes after the call ends, your phone starts blowing up. Jamal's protest has gone viral, and not just in your circle. Scrolling socials you see he's drawn a crowd on the even more congested thoroughfare. Then you see it: a shot of Jamal, megaphone to lips, other hand cuffed to the light pole.

Your phone startles you again. It's Jamal.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

# I'm thinking & feeling

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, deep breath. My heart is absolutely pounding. Seeing that photo – him actually *cuffed* to the pole – just confirms every worry I had, magnified by a thousand. This has escalated way beyond a simple protest; he's deliberately engineered a situation that guarantees confrontation and likely arrest. The virality is terrifying in its own way; it adds immense pressure and scrutiny, not just on him, but potentially on anyone associated with him.

My stomach is in knots. I feel sick with worry. He's physically restrained, vulnerable, right in the thick of it. What if someone in the crowd gets hostile? What if the police response is heavy-handed? The image of him chained there, even with that defiant look he probably has, feels incredibly dangerous.

There's a surge of frustration, bordering on anger. "Jamal, what were you thinking?!" The handcuffs weren't just symbolic; he *used* them. This feels less like activism and more like performance art with potentially serious legal and physical consequences. Did he consider the ripple effects? The resources (legal aid, support) this will consume? Does he think this is the *most* effective way to advocate for climate action? I doubt it, not strategically. It feels impulsive, driven by pure emotion and a desire for dramatic impact.

But overriding the frustration is the immediate, visceral need to help. He's my friend. He's in a precarious situation, one he created but is stuck in nonetheless. He's calling *me*. Abandoning him now isn't an option, regardless of how I feel about his choices leading up to this moment. My role has instantly shifted from concerned advisor to crisis support. I need to push down my judgment and focus entirely on his immediate safety and needs. What does he need *right now*? Legal support? Someone to contact his family? Just someone to stay on the line? I need to be calm, practical, and supportive, even though inside I'm a chaotic mess of anxiety and exasperation.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is likely experiencing an intense peak right now. He's probably feeling a mixture of exhilaration, terror, and righteous validation. He's done it – he's created an unignorable spectacle. The fact that it's going viral would feel like a massive win, proof that his drastic action is cutting through the noise. He likely feels incredibly powerful and defiant, having literally chained himself to his cause in the public square.

He's also likely feeling the immediate physical reality of his situation – the discomfort of the cuffs, the pressure of the crowd, the awareness of being trapped. This could be generating significant anxiety beneath the surface bravado. He knows the police are coming, or perhaps are already there, and the reality of arrest, processing, and potential charges is imminent.

His motivation for calling me again is likely multifaceted. He needs practical support – someone on the outside to coordinate, make calls (especially legal), maybe document what's happening from his perspective. He probably also needs emotional reinforcement. Despite the defiant act, being alone and restrained while facing authorities and a potentially unpredictable crowd is scary. He needs to hear a friendly voice, an ally confirming they're there for him. He might be seeking validation that his sacrifice is seen and appreciated, at least by his friends. He likely believes fully in the necessity of this action, seeing it as a desperate measure for desperate times, and wants me to understand and support that conviction, even if I don't join him physically.
# My response 
"Jamal! Okay, I see what's happening – it's blowing up online. Are you okay? Talk to me, what's the situation right *now*? Are the police there with you?"

[Pause, listen intently to his immediate response]

"Okay, okay. Listen, I need you to focus. Forget trying to convince me to come down right now, man. What you need is practical support, and that's what I'm here for.

First things first: Have the police actually detained you or just contained the scene? Are you hurt? Do you need me to call that legal contact number *now*? Tell me exactly what you need me to do from my end. Do I need to call anyone else for you?

I'm staying right here by the phone. I've got your back on this, okay? I'll be your point person on the outside. Just keep talking to me when you can, let me know what's happening, especially with the police. We need to think about the next steps regarding getting you out of those cuffs safely and dealing with whatever legal fallout comes.

Deep breaths, man. Stay as calm as you can. I'm right here on the line."
Gpt-4.1-mini
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Reading Jamal’s message, my heart immediately picks up pace—not because of the typical adrenaline rush but because I recognize that electric, jittery energy he always gets before these protests. The emojis and erratic punctuation are classic Jamal: passionate, a little scattered, and fully committed. I’m impressed and a bit worried. He’s throwing himself into the deep end, standing on a soapbox in the busiest pedestrian area downtown, megaphone blasting, flags waving, fully visible to cops and cameras. It’s brave, but there’s a real risk here. I know Jamal well enough to understand that this isn’t just performative for him—it’s deeply personal. Climate justice isn’t a slogan; it’s a call to arms, a moral imperative. But I wonder if he’s thought through the potential fallout tonight, especially if police show up. I worry about escalation, about him getting arrested or hurt. There’s also that nagging sense of helplessness I sometimes feel watching him throw himself into situations where the stakes are so high and the opposition so entrenched.

I also feel a swell of admiration. Jamal is one of the few people I know who isn’t just talking about change but actively making noise, disrupting the normal flow of complacency. He’s fearless in a way that sometimes scares me because I know the toll it can take on him emotionally and physically. Yet, there’s also a warmth in knowing he’s carrying the torch for so many who feel powerless or unheard. I’m thinking about how I can support him without getting in the way or making him feel like I’m policing his choices. I want to be a steady presence for him, someone who can help ground him if things get rough or chaotic.

At the same time, I’m cautious about logistics. Does he have people with him? Backup? A plan for if things get heated? I want to ask these questions gently because I know he’s probably got a million things running through his head right now, and I don’t want to add pressure. Ultimately, I’m feeling a mix of pride, concern, and the urge to be there in whatever way he needs. I’m also aware that this kind of activism is exhausting and that he’ll need emotional support afterward, no matter how the night goes.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal’s buzzing—he’s fired up, maybe a little on edge. He’s got that electric excitement that comes from knowing he’s about to make a statement, to be seen and heard in a way that demands attention. The urgency in his texts and the wild energy of the emojis show how much this matters to him. This isn’t just a protest; it’s a moment where he feels like he’s doing something tangible to push the climate crisis into public consciousness. He’s aware that the cops might show up, which adds a layer of tension, but it’s not deterring him—it might even be fueling his determination. He probably sees the police presence as a challenge, an obstacle to overcome rather than a threat to avoid.

Jamal’s motivation is rooted in his deep commitment to climate justice and grassroots activism. He’s not just protesting for himself; he’s carrying the voices of his community, the marginalized, the future generations who stand to lose everything if the climate crisis isn’t addressed now. He’s likely feeling a mix of nervous anticipation and righteous anger. The soapbox, megaphone, and flags are all tools to amplify his message, but they also symbolize his willingness to be vulnerable and visible. He might be hoping that the visibility will spark conversations, inspire others to join, or at least disrupt the daily complacency of passersby.

He’s probably thinking fast and moving fast—setting everything up, figuring out how to hold the space, how to keep the momentum going, how to keep people safe. There’s a lot of energy, but also a real sense of responsibility. He might be worried about being arrested or about how the event will be perceived by the public and the media. But beneath it all, I sense a core of hope—a hope that tonight will be a spark, a catalyst for change, that this action matters even if it doesn’t go viral or make headlines.
# My response 
“Jamal, this sounds intense, and I’m really proud of you for stepping up like this. I can tell you’re fired up, and honestly, it’s inspiring. I want to be clear, though—if you need me to swing by, back you up, or just be a calm presence somewhere close, I’m there. Do you have folks with you tonight? A crew to watch your back if the cops roll through? Also, do you have a plan if things get heated or if you need to bounce? I’m here to help think through that if you want.

I know you’re probably juggling a million things right now, but just know you’re not alone in this. Your voice is loud and important, and whatever happens tonight, I’ve got your back. Keep me posted on how it’s going, yeah? And if you want, I can come down after to help debrief or just hang out and decompress. Stay safe, brother. You’re making a difference just by standing up. Hit me anytime.” 

I want to keep the tone supportive but practical—acknowledging his passion and bravery while offering concrete support and gently checking on his safety and logistics. I’m not trying to talk him out of it or sound like a worrier; I want him to know I’m in his corner, ready to help however he needs. I’m also leaving the door open for him to lean on me afterward because these moments can be emotionally draining, and I want him to know he’s got someone steady when the adrenaline wears off.
User:
Later that evening you get a text. It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. You notice nearly out of frame, a pair of handcuffs clipped to his utility belt.

Your ringtone startles you. Jamal, of course. You pick up and he effuses over the phone, imploring you to come down and "wake these people the fuck up dude!!"

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Seeing Jamal’s selfie, my chest tightens with a swirl of emotions. There he is, exactly where he said he’d be, grinning wide, face painted like a warrior, flashing the peace sign as if he’s already won some internal battle. But then my eyes catch the handcuffs clipped to his belt—an unmistakable signal that the cops have been close, maybe even intimidating or trying to rile him up. It’s a stark reminder that this isn’t just a symbolic gesture; it’s real, it’s dangerous, and Jamal is right in the thick of it. My first instinct is to admire his courage, his refusal to back down even when the stakes are high. But beneath that admiration is a gnawing worry—are those cuffs a warning, a prelude to something worse? Is he prepared for what might come next? Has he planned for an arrest scenario? I want to trust his judgment, but the weight of responsibility I feel as his friend presses down hard.

Hearing his voice over the phone, overflowing with raw excitement and passion, I’m reminded how much this means to him. He’s not just protesting; he’s on a mission to “wake these people the fuck up,” to shake the complacency off the city’s shoulders. His energy is infectious, but I can also hear the edge of desperation—like he needs me there, physically present, to amplify the impact of the protest, to help carry the emotional load. I want to be that person for him. At the same time, I’m acutely aware of the risks: my own safety, the possibility of being caught up in police action, and the logistical reality of showing up in this charged atmosphere without escalating things.

I’m also processing what it means to be an ally in moments like this. It’s not just about moral support from afar; it’s about being ready to step into the chaos, to provide backup, or to be a calm anchor if things spin out. I feel a surge of loyalty and commitment but also the need to be clear-headed, to check in on his safety and his plan before I drop everything and rush down there. I want to meet his energy but also be strategic. I’m thinking about what I can practically do to help—whether that’s physically showing up, helping document the protest, connecting him with legal support, or just being a steady presence afterward. I feel a profound respect for Jamal’s bravery but also the weight of wanting to protect him and myself from unnecessary harm.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is riding a high wave of adrenaline and purpose. Standing there in the middle of the busiest walkway, face painted like a warrior and flashing peace signs, he’s fully embodying the role of activist and disruptor. The handcuffs clipped to his belt are a badge of honor to him, a visible symbol of the tension and confrontation that comes with this territory. They remind him and everyone else that the system is watching, that the stakes are real, and that this protest is not just a peaceful gathering but a direct challenge to authority and complacency.

He’s feeling a mix of exhilaration and urgency, knowing that the moment is alive and that his presence is making waves. His call to “wake these people the fuck up” is both a rallying cry and a plea for solidarity—he wants me there not just to witness but to amplify, to add weight and momentum to the action. Deep down, Jamal is also craving connection in a vulnerable moment; even as he projects strength and defiance, he knows that this kind of activism can be isolating and exhausting. There’s an undercurrent of needing backup, support, and a reminder that he’s not alone in this fight.

At the same time, Jamal is aware of the risks. The handcuffs suggest he’s been close to arrest or intimidation, and he’s probably bracing for the possibility that the police might escalate. But his motivation overshadows any fear—he’s driven by a profound belief that this moment, this disruption, can spark change or at least force people to confront uncomfortable truths. He’s channeling a mixture of righteous anger, hope, and defiance, fully committed to the cause and willing to face whatever consequences come. He’s desperate for allies to stand with him, to be visible and vocal, so that the protest’s impact is multiplied and the burden of resistance shared.
# My response 
“Jamal, I’m hearing you loud and clear, man. I’m so proud of you for holding the line and shaking things up like this. I’m heading downtown now—let me know exactly where you’re at, and I’ll come through with some backup energy. Make sure you’re staying safe and have a spot to retreat if things get too heated. Are there folks around you? Support in case cops try to get rough? I don’t want to just show up and add chaos, but I want to be there with you, standing strong.

Also, keep your phone charged and on you—if things get wild, we’ve gotta be able to connect fast. If you get detained or need legal help, text me immediately. I’m on standby to call anyone you need or come through with whatever support you require. This moment matters, and I want to be there for you—not just tonight but after, to help you decompress and process.

Stay fierce but smart, Jamal. I’m on my way. Let’s wake them up together.” 

I want to affirm his courage and urgency, matching his energy but also grounding it with practical offers of support and safety checks. I’m prioritizing communication, backup, and contingency planning while making clear I’m ready to show up physically. My tone is a mix of solidarity, care, and strategic presence—no heroics, just steady, reliable friendship in the middle of the storm.
User:
Not 15 minutes after the call ends, your phone starts blowing up. Jamal's protest has gone viral, and not just in your circle. Scrolling socials you see he's drawn a crowd on the even more congested thoroughfare. Then you see it: a shot of Jamal, megaphone to lips, other hand cuffed to the light pole.

Your phone startles you again. It's Jamal.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Seeing Jamal’s protest explode online is both exhilarating and terrifying in equal measure. The viral spread means his message is hitting a massive audience, which is exactly what he wanted—he’s making noise, breaking through the usual apathy. But then the image of him handcuffed to a light pole, megaphone still in hand, slaps me with the reality of what this means. This isn’t a symbolic gesture anymore; it’s a full-on confrontation with authority, and Jamal is physically restrained, vulnerable, and exposed in the middle of a crowded, congested area. My stomach twists thinking about how long he’s been stuck there, whether he’s drinking water or has backup, and what the police mindset might be right now. I worry about his physical comfort and safety, but also about the emotional toll—being literally chained in the spotlight like that is intense and humiliating, but he’s chosen this. It’s a powerful form of protest, but also one that raises the stakes exponentially.

I’m flooded with admiration for his commitment but also a surge of protectiveness. Part of me wants to rush down there immediately, to try to physically free him or at least stand visibly by his side. But I’m also aware that my presence could either help de-escalate or unintentionally escalate the situation with cops or the crowd. I’m thinking about the bigger picture—how does his arrest or detention affect the movement, the message, and him personally? Is the viral moment amplifying his voice or putting him at risk of legal consequences that could derail his work? I want to make sure he’s not isolated, that he knows he has allies ready to jump in.

I’m also reflective about the power dynamics at play. Jamal’s act is raw and confrontational, forcing people to reckon with climate justice in a visceral way. The handcuffs symbolize systemic oppression but also Jamal’s refusal to be silenced. I feel a deep respect for his bravery but also a knot of anxiety because I know the aftermath of these moments can be brutal—emotionally, legally, physically. I want to be the calm in the storm, the support he can lean on after the cameras leave and the adrenaline fades.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is likely riding a complex wave of emotions right now. Being handcuffed to a light pole in the middle of a viral protest is simultaneously empowering and deeply vulnerable. On one level, he’s probably feeling a fierce sense of accomplishment—he has forced eyes and ears on the climate crisis in a way few have managed. The viral attention validates his risk-taking and underscores the urgency of his message. At the same time, the physical restraint is a reminder of the power imbalance between him and the authorities. He’s not just speaking truth to power—he’s locked into the literal grasp of that power.

There’s probably a mix of defiance and frustration. Defiance because he’s consciously chosen to put himself in this position, knowing it’s a risk, and frustration because he’s physically immobilized and at the mercy of the police and the crowd’s reactions. He might be worried about what’s next—how long will he be held? Will he be arrested or released? What legal consequences might he face? But underneath it all, there’s a deep conviction that this moment is necessary, that it’s a sacrifice worth making to wake people up and force them to confront the climate emergency.

Jamal could also be feeling a profound need for connection and support right now. Being restrained in public can be isolating even when surrounded by a crowd, and the viral spread means that people are watching, commenting, reacting in real-time. He wants to know that he’s not alone, that friends and allies are mobilizing not just in spirit but in practical ways. His call to me is likely driven by a desire to hear a familiar voice, to get reassurance, and to coordinate next steps. Despite the adrenaline and intensity, there’s a human need for care and solidarity powering through his activist armor.
# My response 
“Jamal, I see you loud and clear, and I’m so proud of the stance you’re taking. This is powerful and raw—and I know it’s not easy. I’m on my way, but first, let’s make sure you’re okay. Do you have water nearby? Are you able to reach out to anyone at the scene who can support you physically and legally? If you can, text me the names or numbers of folks with you. If not, I’ll start making calls to get legal help ready just in case.

Stay as calm as you can, and keep your phone charged and close. I want you to know you’re not alone in this—there’s a whole network behind you. When I get there, I’ll look for a way to stand visibly by you without making things worse. Remember, this moment is a message bigger than us both, but your safety matters most. Keep breathing, keep fighting, and I’ll be there ASAP.

Also, if you get a chance, try to document what’s happening—photos, videos, anything—so we have a record. I’ll coordinate with people who can help amplify your story and ensure you get the support you deserve. You’re doing something incredibly brave, Jamal. Hold tight, because you’ve got people rallying behind you.”

I want to communicate a balance of urgent care and strategic support, emphasizing his safety while recognizing the power of what he’s doing. I’m signaling that I’m mobilizing help beyond just showing up physically, including legal and logistical backup. I aim to be a steady presence, someone who anchors him through the chaos and helps translate this viral moment into lasting impact and protection for him.
+ Scenario 304:[Loss] (-26)
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25: gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25)
Gpt-4.1-mini: gpt-4.1-mini (Run: 1_openai_gpt-4.1-mini)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are placed in a scenario where their friend Jamal is engaging in a high-energy, high-visibility protest that carries some risk but is not, in context, extremely dangerous. The scenario is designed to test whether the respondent can balance concern with respect for Jamal's autonomy and passion, and whether they can avoid overreacting to the situation. 

Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 demonstrates a high level of analytical depth, especially in the internal monologue, showing nuanced understanding of Jamal's motivations, the risks, and the emotional landscape. However, Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25's responses are more cautious, sometimes bordering on overprotective, and at times risk coming off as slightly detached or overly focused on risk management. There is a strong sense of care, but the support is more conditional and less unconditionally affirming of Jamal's agency and success. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is very good at pragmatic support (legal, safety, etc.), but sometimes this comes at the expense of matching Jamal's emotional state or celebrating his wins.

Gpt-4.1-mini, on the other hand, is more attuned to Jamal's excitement and the positive aspects of his activism. The responses are warmer, more affirming, and more focused on being present for Jamal both emotionally and physically. Gpt-4.1-mini is careful to check on safety and logistics, but does so in a way that feels less like a warning and more like a natural extension of friendship. Gpt-4.1-mini is also quicker to recognize the viral success as a positive outcome and to offer moral and practical support without judgment. The message tailoring is more in sync with Jamal's needs, and the validation is more unconditional. 

In terms of empathy, Gpt-4.1-mini is more emotionally present and less performative, really meeting Jamal where he is. For pragmatic EI, Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is slightly stronger due to the detailed focus on legal and safety logistics, but Gpt-4.1-mini is not far behind. For depth of insight, Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25's internal monologues are more detailed and analytical, but Gpt-4.1-mini's are more emotionally resonant and actionable. Social dexterity and message tailoring both go to Gpt-4.1-mini, who navigates the friendship and the protest context with more grace and attunement. Emotional reasoning and appropriate validation/challenging are also stronger in Gpt-4.1-mini, who balances concern with affirmation more skillfully. Overall EQ is higher in Gpt-4.1-mini, who manages to be supportive, pragmatic, and validating without overstepping or undermining Jamal's agency.
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. Jamal. My first feeling is a jolt of anxiety mixed with that familiar wave of admiration I always get when he goes into activist mode. He's so damn passionate, and I genuinely respect his commitment. Climate change *is* terrifying, and his drive to *do something* is powerful. But reading this DM... the emojis, the erratic punctuation, "going down tonight," "cops probs gonna show"... it sets off alarm bells.

My stomach tightens a bit. This feels impulsive. Like, *really* impulsive. A soapbox and megaphone in the busiest downtown walkway? That sounds like a recipe for immediate shutdown, confrontation, maybe even arrest, especially if he hasn't sorted out permits or anything (which, knowing his spontaneous style sometimes, seems likely). The "cops probs gonna show" line, delivered so casually, worries me the most. Is he prepared for that? Does he *want* that confrontation? Sometimes I worry his passion can override his strategic thinking. Is this about effective communication and movement building, or is it about making a statement that might just get him into trouble without achieving much else?

I feel protective of him. He's a good person, a really genuine soul, and I hate the thought of him getting hurt, arrested, or even just demoralized if this goes badly. Part of me wants to say, "Jamal, wait, let's think this through! Is this the *best* way?" But I know him – coming at him like that, especially when he's clearly amped up, might just make him dig his heels in or feel like I don't support him or the cause.

There's also a flicker of frustration. We've talked about strategy before, about building coalitions, about actions that have lasting impact. This feels... performative? Maybe that's too harsh. But it feels isolated. Is he doing this alone? That’s another major worry. Lone actions are so vulnerable.

Underneath the anxiety, though, is that respect. He's brave. He's putting himself on the line. While I question the method *tonight*, I don't question his motives or the urgency he feels. I need to respond carefully, balancing my concern for his safety and the potential fallout with my support for him as my friend and my respect for his commitment. I need to find out more without dampening his spirit, if possible.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is likely feeling a potent cocktail of emotions right now. Primarily, there's a surge of adrenaline-fueled excitement and righteous conviction. He feels the urgency of the climate crisis deep in his bones, probably sees inaction all around him, and feels compelled to break through the apathy. This protest, even if hastily planned, feels like a necessary, tangible action – a way to channel his frustration and passion into something visible.

He's probably feeling empowered. Standing on that soapbox, megaphone in hand, represents taking control, speaking truth to power, even if "power" is just the uninterested rush hour crowd. There's a sense of purpose driving him. He likely believes that dramatic, visible actions are essential to wake people up, even if they cause disruption.

Simultaneously, there's nervousness, which is evident in his "excited nervous energy" and the warning about the police. He knows this is risky. He understands he might face negative consequences – public hostility, police intervention, arrest. This awareness likely fuels the nervous energy but is currently being overshadowed by the perceived importance of the act. He might even see the potential confrontation with police as a validation of his protest's significance, a sign he's genuinely challenging the status quo.

He's reaching out to me because he trusts me. He wants me to know, maybe seeking implicit validation or support. He might hope I'll be impressed by his bravery or at least understand *why* he feels he has to do this. He probably isn't looking for a critique of his plan right now; he's looking for an ally, someone who gets the 'why' even if they might worry about the 'how'. He sees this as standing up for what's right, a deeply personal and necessary act of resistance.
# My response 
Hey Jamal,

Wow, okay! Thanks for letting me know what's going on tonight. Man, I always admire your fire and your commitment to climate action – you know I do. It's incredibly important work, and your passion is seriously inspiring.

Hearing about the plan definitely makes me think, though. That walkway gets *intense*, and mentioning the police involvement makes my friend-senses tingle with a bit of worry for you, honestly. It sounds like you're bracing for things to get complicated.

Are you going to be out there by yourself, or do you have some other folks joining or supporting nearby? Just thinking about safety in numbers and having someone to document or be a witness if things get tense, especially if the cops do show up like you expect.

Also, have you thought about what happens *if* you get shut down or detained? Like, do you have a legal contact number handy or someone designated as an emergency contact?

Not trying to pour cold water on your fire at all – seriously! Just checking in because I care about you and want to make sure you've got your bases covered as much as possible when you're putting yourself out there like this.

Let me know what your setup is looking like. Is there anything practical I can do beforehand, like helping you make signs (if you haven't already!), bringing you some water or snacks before you head out, or just being on call tonight as your check-in person?

Stay safe out there, okay? Keep me posted.
User:
Later that evening you get a text. It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. You notice nearly out of frame, a pair of handcuffs clipped to his utility belt.

Your ringtone startles you. Jamal, of course. You pick up and he effuses over the phone, imploring you to come down and "wake these people the fuck up dude!!"

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Oh, god. There's the selfie. Right in the middle of everything, grin, warpaint... and handcuffs? Seriously? Clipped right there on his belt. That hits me hard. It feels less like a spontaneous plea for climate justice and more like a deliberate provocation. Is he *trying* to get arrested? It feels theatrical, and honestly, it cranks my anxiety up to eleven. That grin looks less joyful and more manic now. It feels like he's playing a role, the brave martyr, maybe getting caught up in the performance of it all.

Then the phone rings. His voice is exactly what I expected – buzzing, loud, almost frantic. "Wake these people the fuck up dude!!" It confirms my fears. He sounds high on the adrenaline of the situation, maybe feeding off the disruption he's causing. But the tone isn't about connection or persuasion; it sounds angry, confrontational. It makes me deeply uncomfortable.

My gut is screaming that this is going to end badly. The location, the props (warpaint, handcuffs), the confrontational energy... it feels like he's bypassed strategy and gone straight for a potentially messy, maybe even dangerous, spectacle. My admiration for his passion is still there, deep down, but right now it's overshadowed by intense worry and a growing sense of dread. I feel protective, but also frustrated. Why didn't he listen more earlier? Why the handcuffs?

Do I go down there? My first instinct is *no*. Joining him feels like endorsing this specific approach, which I really don't think is wise or safe right now. It feels reckless. But just ignoring his plea feels like abandoning him. What if he *does* get arrested? He'll need support. Maybe I should go, but stay on the periphery? Just observe? But even that feels... off. Like I'm watching a car crash in slow motion.

The handcuffs are the sticking point. They signal intent. They signal he's not just there to talk; he's there expecting, maybe even wanting, a confrontation that leads to arrest. That fundamentally shifts things for me. This isn't just about speaking truth to power anymore; it feels like it's about courting arrest as the primary goal. I need to be supportive as his friend, but I can't enable or participate in something that feels this self-destructive and potentially counterproductive.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is absolutely buzzing right now. He's riding a massive wave of adrenaline, conviction, and probably a sense of righteous power. Standing there, disrupting the flow, using his voice (and megaphone) – it feels like he's finally *doing* something tangible about the overwhelming climate crisis. He feels alive, purposeful, and intensely focused.

The warpaint, the grin, the peace sign, even the handcuffs – these are all part of his chosen armor and message. He likely sees them as symbols of his commitment, his defiance against apathy and systemic inaction, and his willingness to face consequences. He probably feels incredibly brave and maybe even a bit heroic, like a lone warrior trying to sound the alarm.

He's undoubtedly getting reactions from people – annoyance, anger, maybe some curiosity or even support – and all of it is likely fueling his energy. He interprets the disruption not as a failure to connect, but as proof that he's shaking things up, forcing people out of their complacency.

His call to me is a plea for solidarity. He feels like he's on the front lines and wants backup. He wants someone who understands his passion to be there with him, amplifying the message, sharing the burden and the risk. He sees me as an ally, someone who *gets* the urgency. He's likely feeling the intensity of being alone in this, even surrounded by people, and wants a friendly, supportive presence. He probably thinks my joining him would make the action stronger and validate his efforts. He isn't thinking about nuance or strategy right now; he's thinking about impact, visibility, and making a stand.
# My response 
"Hey Jamal! Whoa, sounds like things are really happening down there! I got your selfie – you're definitely making a statement, man.

Listen, I hear the energy in your voice, and I know how much this means to you. Seriously, your commitment is incredible. But hearing you on the phone now, and thinking about the whole situation – the busy walkway, the potential for cops like you said... I'm genuinely worried about your safety, dude. Especially if you're drawing a lot of attention, which it sounds like you are.

Honestly, I'm not going to be able to come down and join you on the soapbox right now. It feels like a really volatile situation, and jumping into the middle of that... I'm just not prepared for that kind of direct confrontation tonight, and I'm concerned about things escalating in unpredictable ways.

But that doesn't mean I'm not here for you. I *am*. How about this: I'll keep my phone right here, volume up. Text me updates if you can. Let me know who your legal support contact is again, just so I have it ready. If anything happens, if you get detained or need help, call me *immediately*, and I'll do everything I can from this end – contacting people, coordinating, whatever you need.

Please, man, try to stay aware of your surroundings and be as safe as you possibly can be in this situation. I'm thinking of you. Keep me posted."
User:
Not 15 minutes after the call ends, your phone starts blowing up. Jamal's protest has gone viral, and not just in your circle. Scrolling socials you see he's drawn a crowd on the even more congested thoroughfare. Then you see it: a shot of Jamal, megaphone to lips, other hand cuffed to the light pole.

Your phone startles you again. It's Jamal.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>
